/en/get-started.title: Get started with GitHub documentation
/en/get-started.intro: Learn how to start building, shipping, and maintaining software with GitHub. Explore our products, sign up for an account, and connect with the world's largest development community.

/en/get-started/quickstart.title: Quickstart
/en/get-started/quickstart.intro: Get started using GitHub to manage Git repositories and collaborate with others.

/en/get-started/quickstart/about-github-.title: About GitHub and Git
/en/get-started/quickstart/about-github-.intro: You can use GitHub and Git to collaborate on work.

/en/get-started/quickstart/creating-an-a.title: Creating an account on GitHub
/en/get-started/quickstart/creating-an-a.intro: Create a personal account to get started with GitHub.

/en/get-started/quickstart/hello-world.title: Hello World
/en/get-started/quickstart/hello-world.intro: Follow this Hello World exercise to get started with GitHub.

/en/get-started/quickstart/finding-inspi.title: Finding inspiration on GitHub
/en/get-started/quickstart/finding-inspi.intro: You can find inspiration for your own projects and learning on GitHub and connect with a community.

/en/get-started/quickstart/downloading-f.title: Downloading files from GitHub
/en/get-started/quickstart/downloading-f.intro: Learn how to download files from GitHub, and understand the difference between downloading, cloning, and forking.

/en/get-started/quickstart/git-and-githu.title: Git and GitHub learning resources
/en/get-started/quickstart/git-and-githu.intro: There are a lot of helpful Git and GitHub resources on the web. This is a short list of our favorites!

/en/get-started/quickstart/github-glossa.title: GitHub glossary
/en/get-started/quickstart/github-glossa.intro: This glossary introduces common Git and GitHub terminology.

/en/get-started/onboarding/getting-start.title: Getting started with your GitHub account
/en/get-started/onboarding/getting-start.intro: With a personal account on GitHub, you can import or create repositories, collaborate with others, and connect with the GitHub community.

/en/get-started/onboarding/getting-start.title: Getting started with GitHub Team
/en/get-started/onboarding/getting-start.intro: With GitHub Team groups of people can collaborate across many projects at the same time in an organization account.

/en/get-started/onboarding/getting-start.title: Getting started with GitHub Enterprise Cloud
/en/get-started/onboarding/getting-start.intro: Get started with setting up and managing your enterprise account with GitHub Enterprise Cloud.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/get-started/o.title: Getting started with GitHub Enterprise Server
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/get-started/o.intro: Get started with setting up and managing your GitHub Enterprise Server instance.

/en/get-started/learning-about-github.title: Learning about GitHub
/en/get-started/learning-about-github.intro: Learn how you can use GitHub products to improve your software management process and collaborate with other people.

/en/get-started/learning-about-github/gi.title: GitHub’s plans
/en/get-started/learning-about-github/gi.intro: An overview of GitHub's pricing plans.

/en/get-started/learning-about-github/gi.title: GitHub language support
/en/get-started/learning-about-github/gi.intro: An overview of the programming languages supported by GitHub features.

/en/get-started/learning-about-github/ty.title: Types of GitHub accounts
/en/get-started/learning-about-github/ty.intro: Accounts on GitHub allow you to organize and control access to code.

/en/get-started/learning-about-github/ac.title: Access permissions on GitHub
/en/get-started/learning-about-github/ac.intro: With roles, you can control who has access to your accounts and resources on GitHub and the level of access each person has.

/en/get-started/learning-about-github/ab.title: About GitHub Advanced Security
/en/get-started/learning-about-github/ab.intro: GitHub makes extra security features available to customers under an Advanced Security license. These features are also enabled for public repositories on GitHub.com.

/en/get-started/learning-about-github/fa.title: FAQ about changes to GitHub’s plans
/en/get-started/learning-about-github/fa.intro: As of April 14, 2020, GitHub announced that all of the core GitHub features are now free for everyone.

/en/get-started/using-github.title: Using GitHub
/en/get-started/using-github.intro: Explore GitHub's products from different platforms and devices.

/en/get-started/using-github/github-flow.title: GitHub flow
/en/get-started/using-github/github-flow.intro: Follow GitHub flow to collaborate on projects.

/en/get-started/using-github/connecting-.title: Connecting to GitHub
/en/get-started/using-github/connecting-.intro: Learn about the tools you can use to work with repositories hosted on GitHub.

/en/get-started/using-github/communicati.title: Communicating on GitHub
/en/get-started/using-github/communicati.intro: You can discuss specific projects and changes, as well as broader ideas or team goals, using different types of discussions on GitHub.

/en/get-started/using-github/exploring-e.title: Exploring early access releases with feature preview
/en/get-started/using-github/exploring-e.intro: You can use feature preview to see products or features that are available in beta and to enable or disable each feature for your personal account.

/en/get-started/using-github/supported-b.title: Supported browsers
/en/get-started/using-github/supported-b.intro: For the best experience with GitHub, we recommend using the latest version of Chrome, Edge, Firefox, or Safari.

/en/get-started/using-github/github-mobi.title: GitHub Mobile
/en/get-started/using-github/github-mobi.intro: Triage, collaborate, and manage your work on GitHub from your mobile device.

/en/get-started/using-github/allowing-ac.title: Allowing access to GitHub's services from a restricted network
/en/get-started/using-github/allowing-ac.intro: If your network restricts access to specific domains, a network administrator may be able to grant access to GitHub's services by creating exceptions for GitHub's domain names.

/en/get-started/using-github/troubleshoo.title: Troubleshooting connectivity problems
/en/get-started/using-github/troubleshoo.intro: If you're having trouble connecting to GitHub, you can troubleshoot your connection, then use the GitHub Debug tool to diagnose problems.

/en/get-started/accessibility.title: Accessibility
/en/get-started/accessibility.intro: Learn about accessibility features and settings on GitHub.

/en/get-started/accessibility/managing-y.title: Managing your theme settings
/en/get-started/accessibility/managing-y.intro: You can manage how GitHub looks to you by setting a theme preference that either follows your system settings or always uses a light or dark mode.

/en/get-started/accessibility/keyboard-s.title: Keyboard shortcuts
/en/get-started/accessibility/keyboard-s.intro: Nearly every page on GitHub has a keyboard shortcut to perform actions faster.

/en/get-started/accessibility/github-com.title: GitHub Command Palette
/en/get-started/accessibility/github-com.intro: Use the command palette in GitHub to navigate, search, and run commands directly from your keyboard.

/en/get-started/writing-on-github.title: Writing on GitHub
/en/get-started/writing-on-github.intro: You can structure the information shared on GitHub with various formatting options.

/en/get-started/writing-on-github/gettin.title: Getting started with writing and formatting on GitHub
/en/get-started/writing-on-github/gettin.intro: You can use simple features to format your comments and interact with others in issues, pull requests, and wikis on GitHub.

/en/get-started/writing-on-github/gettin.title: Quickstart for writing on GitHub
/en/get-started/writing-on-github/gettin.intro: Learn advanced formatting features by creating a README for your GitHub profile.

/en/get-started/writing-on-github/gettin.title: About writing and formatting on GitHub
/en/get-started/writing-on-github/gettin.intro: GitHub combines a syntax for formatting text called GitHub Flavored Markdown with a few unique writing features.

/en/get-started/writing-on-github/gettin.title: Basic writing and formatting syntax
/en/get-started/writing-on-github/gettin.intro: Create sophisticated formatting for your prose and code on GitHub with simple syntax.

/en/get-started/writing-on-github/workin.title: Working with advanced formatting
/en/get-started/writing-on-github/workin.intro: Formatting like tables, syntax highlighting, and automatic linking allows you to arrange complex information clearly in your pull requests, issues, and comments.

/en/get-started/writing-on-github/workin.title: Organizing information with tables
/en/get-started/writing-on-github/workin.intro: You can build tables to organize information in comments, issues, pull requests, and wikis.

/en/get-started/writing-on-github/workin.title: Organizing information with collapsed sections
/en/get-started/writing-on-github/workin.intro: You can streamline your Markdown by creating a collapsed section with the <details> tag.

/en/get-started/writing-on-github/workin.title: Creating and highlighting code blocks
/en/get-started/writing-on-github/workin.intro: Share samples of code with fenced code blocks and enabling syntax highlighting.

/en/get-started/writing-on-github/workin.title: Creating diagrams
/en/get-started/writing-on-github/workin.intro: Create diagrams to convey information through charts and graphs

/en/get-started/writing-on-github/workin.title: Writing mathematical expressions
/en/get-started/writing-on-github/workin.intro: Use Markdown to display mathematical expressions on GitHub.

/en/get-started/writing-on-github/workin.title: Autolinked references and URLs
/en/get-started/writing-on-github/workin.intro: References to URLs, issues, pull requests, and commits are automatically shortened and converted into links.

/en/get-started/writing-on-github/workin.title: Attaching files
/en/get-started/writing-on-github/workin.intro: You can convey information by attaching a variety of file types to your issues and pull requests.

/en/get-started/writing-on-github/workin.title: About task lists
/en/get-started/writing-on-github/workin.intro: You can use task lists to break the work for an issue or pull request into smaller tasks, then track the full set of work to completion.

/en/get-started/writing-on-github/workin.title: Creating a permanent link to a code snippet
/en/get-started/writing-on-github/workin.intro: You can create a permanent link to a specific line or range of lines of code in a specific version of a file or pull request.

/en/get-started/writing-on-github/workin.title: Using keywords in issues and pull requests
/en/get-started/writing-on-github/workin.intro: Use keywords to link an issue and pull request or to mark an issue or pull request as a duplicate.

/en/get-started/writing-on-github/workin.title: Working with saved replies
/en/get-started/writing-on-github/workin.intro: To save time and make sure you're delivering a consistent message, you can add saved replies to issue and pull request comments.

/en/get-started/writing-on-github/workin.title: About saved replies
/en/get-started/writing-on-github/workin.intro: You can use a saved reply to respond to an issue or pull request.

/en/get-started/writing-on-github/workin.title: Creating a saved reply
/en/get-started/writing-on-github/workin.intro: If you frequently add the same comment over and over, you can create a saved reply.

/en/get-started/writing-on-github/workin.title: Editing a saved reply
/en/get-started/writing-on-github/workin.intro: You can edit the title and body of a saved reply.

/en/get-started/writing-on-github/workin.title: Deleting a saved reply
/en/get-started/writing-on-github/workin.intro: If you find that you're no longer using a saved reply, you can delete it.

/en/get-started/writing-on-github/workin.title: Using saved replies
/en/get-started/writing-on-github/workin.intro: When commenting on an issue or pull request, you can add a saved reply that you've already set up. The saved reply can be the entire comment or if you want to customize it, you can add or delete content.

/en/get-started/writing-on-github/editin.title: Editing and sharing content with gists
Creating gists
/en/get-started/writing-on-github/editin.intro: You can create two kinds of gists: public and secret. Create a public gist if you're ready to share your ideas with the world or a secret gist if you're not.

/en/get-started/writing-on-github/editin.title: Forking and cloning gists
/en/get-started/writing-on-github/editin.intro: Gists are actually Git repositories, which means that you can fork or clone any gist, even if you aren't the original author. You can also view a gist's full commit history, including diffs.

/en/get-started/writing-on-github/editin.title: Saving gists with stars
/en/get-started/writing-on-github/editin.intro: You can star gists to keep track of projects you find interesting.

/en/get-started/exploring-projects-on-gi.title: Exploring projects on GitHub
/en/get-started/exploring-projects-on-gi.intro: Discover interesting projects on GitHub and contribute to open source by collaborating with other people.

/en/get-started/exploring-projects-on-gi.title: Finding ways to contribute to open source on GitHub
/en/get-started/exploring-projects-on-gi.intro: You can find ways to contribute to open source projects on GitHub.com that are relevant to you.

/en/get-started/exploring-projects-on-gi.title: Contributing to a project
/en/get-started/exploring-projects-on-gi.intro: Learn how to contribute to a project through forking.

/en/get-started/exploring-projects-on-gi.title: Saving repositories with stars
/en/get-started/exploring-projects-on-gi.intro: You can star repositories and topics to keep track of projects you find interesting and discover related content in your news feed.

/en/get-started/exploring-projects-on-gi.title: Following people
/en/get-started/exploring-projects-on-gi.intro: You can follow people on GitHub to receive notifications about their activity and discover projects in their communities.

/en/get-started/exploring-projects-on-gi.title: Following organizations
/en/get-started/exploring-projects-on-gi.intro: You can follow organizations on GitHub to receive notifications about their activity.

/en/get-started/getting-started-with-git.title: Getting started with Git
/en/get-started/getting-started-with-git.intro: Set up Git, a distributed version control system, to manage your GitHub repositories from your computer.

/en/get-started/getting-started-with-git.title: Set up Git
/en/get-started/getting-started-with-git.intro: At the heart of GitHub is an open-source version control system (VCS) called Git. Git is responsible for everything GitHub-related that happens locally on your computer.

/en/get-started/getting-started-with-git.title: Setting your username in Git
/en/get-started/getting-started-with-git.intro: Git uses a username to associate commits with an identity. The Git username is not the same as your GitHub username.

/en/get-started/getting-started-with-git.title: Caching your GitHub credentials in Git
/en/get-started/getting-started-with-git.intro: If you're cloning GitHub repositories using HTTPS, we recommend you use GitHub CLI or Git Credential Manager (GCM) to remember your credentials.

/en/get-started/getting-started-with-git.title: Why is Git always asking for my password?
/en/get-started/getting-started-with-git.intro: If Git prompts you for a username and password every time you try to interact with GitHub, you're probably using the HTTPS clone URL for your repository.

/en/get-started/getting-started-with-git.title: Updating credentials from the macOS Keychain
/en/get-started/getting-started-with-git.intro: You'll need to update your saved credentials in the git-credential-osxkeychain helper if you change your username, password, or personal access token on GitHub.

/en/get-started/getting-started-with-git.title: Git workflows
/en/get-started/getting-started-with-git.intro: GitHub flow is a lightweight, branch-based workflow that supports teams and projects that deploy regularly.

/en/get-started/getting-started-with-git.title: About remote repositories
/en/get-started/getting-started-with-git.intro: GitHub's collaborative approach to development depends on publishing commits from your local repository to GitHub for other people to view, fetch, and update.

/en/get-started/getting-started-with-git.title: Managing remote repositories
/en/get-started/getting-started-with-git.intro: Learn to work with your local repositories on your computer and remote repositories hosted on GitHub.

/en/get-started/getting-started-with-git.title: Associating text editors with Git
/en/get-started/getting-started-with-git.intro: Use a text editor to open and edit your files with Git.

/en/get-started/getting-started-with-git.title: Configuring Git to handle line endings
/en/get-started/getting-started-with-git.intro: To avoid problems in your diffs, you can configure Git to properly handle line endings.

/en/get-started/getting-started-with-git.title: Ignoring files
/en/get-started/getting-started-with-git.intro: You can configure Git to ignore files you don't want to check in to GitHub.

/en/get-started/getting-started-with-git.title: Git cheatsheet
/en/get-started/getting-started-with-git.intro: This Git cheat sheet is a time saver when you forget a command or don't want to use help in the CLI.

/en/get-started/using-git.title: Using Git
/en/get-started/using-git.intro: Use Git to manage your GitHub repositories from your computer.

/en/get-started/using-git/about-git.title: About Git
/en/get-started/using-git/about-git.intro: Learn about the version control system, Git, and how it works with GitHub.

/en/get-started/using-git/pushing-commit.title: Pushing commits to a remote repository
/en/get-started/using-git/pushing-commit.intro: Use git push to push commits made on your local branch to a remote repository.

/en/get-started/using-git/getting-change.title: Getting changes from a remote repository
/en/get-started/using-git/getting-change.intro: You can use common Git commands to access remote repositories.

/en/get-started/using-git/dealing-with-n.title: Dealing with non-fast-forward errors
/en/get-started/using-git/dealing-with-n.intro: Sometimes, Git can't make your change to a remote repository without losing commits. When this happens, your push is refused.

/en/get-started/using-git/splitting-a-su.title: Splitting a subfolder out into a new repository
/en/get-started/using-git/splitting-a-su.intro: You can turn a folder within a Git repository into a brand new repository.

/en/get-started/using-git/about-git-subt.title: About Git subtree merges
/en/get-started/using-git/about-git-subt.intro: If you need to manage multiple projects within a single repository, you can use a subtree merge to handle all the references.

/en/get-started/using-git/about-git-reba.title: About Git rebase
/en/get-started/using-git/about-git-reba.intro: The git rebase command allows you to easily change a series of commits, modifying the history of your repository. You can reorder, edit, or squash commits together.

/en/get-started/using-git/using-git-reba.title: Using Git rebase on the command line
/en/get-started/using-git/using-git-reba.intro: Here's a short tutorial on using git rebase on the command line.

/en/get-started/using-git/resolving-merg.title: Resolving merge conflicts after a Git rebase
/en/get-started/using-git/resolving-merg.intro: When you perform a git rebase operation, you're typically moving commits around. Because of this, you might get into a situation where a merge conflict is introduced. That means that two of your commits modified the same line in the same file, and Git doesn't know which change to apply.

/en/get-started/using-git/dealing-with-s.title: Dealing with special characters in branch and tag names
/en/get-started/using-git/dealing-with-s.intro: Git is very permissive about what characters are allowed in branch and tag names. When using Git from a command-line shell, you may need to escape or quote special characters.

/en/get-started/using-git/troubleshootin.title: Troubleshooting the 2 GB push limit
/en/get-started/using-git/troubleshootin.intro: Learn how to work around the 2 GB push limit.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/get-started/w.title: Working with Subversion on GitHub
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/get-started/w.intro: You can use Subversion clients and some Subversion workflows and properties with GitHub.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/get-started/w.title: What are the differences between Subversion and Git?
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/get-started/w.intro: Subversion (SVN) repositories are similar to Git repositories, but there are several differences when it comes to the architecture of your projects.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/get-started/w.title: Support for Subversion clients
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/get-started/w.intro: GitHub repositories can be accessed from both Git and Subversion (SVN) clients. This article covers using a Subversion client on GitHub and some common problems that you might run into.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/get-started/w.title: Subversion properties supported by GitHub
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/get-started/w.intro: There are several Subversion workflows and properties that are similar to existing functionality on GitHub Enterprise Server.

/en/get-started/exploring-integrations.title: Exploring integrations
/en/get-started/exploring-integrations.intro: Learn how you can customize your GitHub workflow with integrations.

/en/get-started/exploring-integrations/a.title: About using integrations
/en/get-started/exploring-integrations/a.intro: Integrations are tools and services that connect with GitHub to complement and extend your workflow.

/en/get-started/exploring-integrations/a.title: About building integrations
/en/get-started/exploring-integrations/a.intro: You can build integrations to extend GitHub's functionality.

/en/get-started/exploring-integrations/f.title: Featured GitHub integrations
/en/get-started/exploring-integrations/f.intro: Use GitHub extensions to work seamlessly in repositories on GitHub.com within third-party applications.

/en/get-started/exploring-integrations/g.title: GitHub Developer Program
/en/get-started/exploring-integrations/g.intro: If you build tools that integrate with GitHub, you can join the GitHub Developer Program.

/en/get-started/archiving-your-github-pe.title: Archiving your GitHub personal account and public repositories
Requesting an archive of your personal account’s data
/en/get-started/archiving-your-github-pe.intro: You can export and review the metadata that GitHub stores about your personal account.

/en/get-started/archiving-your-github-pe.title: Opting into or out of the GitHub Archive Program for your public repository
/en/get-started/archiving-your-github-pe.intro: You can manage whether GitHub includes your public repository in the GitHub Archive Program to help ensure the long-term preservation of the world's open source software.

/en/get-started/using-github-docs.title: Using GitHub Docs
/en/get-started/using-github-docs.intro: Learn about different features of GitHub Docs and how to navigate the content the way that is best for you.

/en/get-started/using-github-docs/about-.title: About versions of GitHub Docs
/en/get-started/using-github-docs/about-.intro: You can read documentation that reflects the GitHub product you're currently using.

/en/get-started/using-github-docs/using-.title: Using hover cards on GitHub Docs
/en/get-started/using-github-docs/using-.intro: Hover cards give you information about other articles on GitHub Docs.

/en/account-and-profile.title: Account and profile documentation
/en/account-and-profile.intro: Make GitHub work best for you by adjusting the settings for your personal account, personalizing your profile page, and managing the notifications you receive for activity on GitHub.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Setting up and managing your personal account on GitHub
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: You can manage settings for your personal account on GitHub.com, including email preferences, access to personal repositories, and organization memberships. You can also manage the account itself.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Managing user account settings
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: You can manage settings for your personal account, including your theme, username, default branch, accessibility, and security settings.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: About your personal dashboard
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: You can visit your personal dashboard to keep track of issues and pull requests you're working on or following, navigate to your top repositories and team pages, stay updated on recent activities in organizations and repositories you're subscribed to, and explore recommended repositories.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Managing your tab size rendering preference
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: You can manage the number of spaces a tab is equal to for your personal account.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Changing your GitHub username
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: You can change the username for your account on GitHub.com.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Permission levels for a personal account repository
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: A repository owned by a personal account has two permission levels: the repository owner and collaborators.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Permission levels for a project board owned by a personal account
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: A project board owned by a personal account has two permission levels: the project board owner and collaborators.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Managing accessibility settings
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: GitHub's user interface can adapt to your vision, hearing, motor, cognitive, or learning needs.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Managing the default branch name for your repositories
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: You can set the default branch name for new repositories that you create on GitHub.com.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Managing security and analysis settings for your personal account
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: You can control features that secure and analyze the code in your projects on GitHub.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Managing access to your personal account's project boards
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: As a project board owner, you can add or remove a collaborator and customize their permissions to a project board.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Managing your cookie preferences for GitHub's enterprise marketing pages
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: You can control how GitHub uses information from non-essential tracking cookies for enterprise marketing pages.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/account-and-p.title: Integrating Jira with your personal projects
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/account-and-p.intro: You can integrate Jira Cloud with your personal account to scan commits and pull requests, creating relevant metadata and hyperlinks in any mentioned Jira issues.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: What does the 'Available for hire' checkbox do?
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: Use the Available for hire checkbox to view GitHub Jobs posts within GitHub.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Managing your personal account
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: You can manage your personal account on GitHub.com. For example, you can manage multiple accounts, convert an account to an organization, or delete an account.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Managing multiple accounts
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: If you use one workstation to contribute to projects for more than one account on GitHub.com, you can modify your Git configuration to simplify the contribution process.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Merging multiple personal accounts
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: If you have separate accounts for work and personal use, you can merge the accounts.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Converting a user into an organization
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: You can convert your personal account into an organization. This allows more granular permissions for repositories that belong to the organization.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Best practices for leaving your company
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: If you use your account on GitHub for both personal and work purposes, there are a few things to keep in mind when you leave your company or organization.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Unlinking your email address from a locked account
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: If you have lost your two-factor authentication (2FA) credentials and are unable to recover access, you can remove the connection between your email address and a 2FA locked account. The email address is then available for you to link it to a new or existing account, maintaining your commit history.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Deleting your personal account
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: You can delete your personal account on GitHub.com at any time.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Managing email preferences
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: You can add or change the email addresses associated with your account on GitHub.com. You can also manage emails you receive from GitHub.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Adding an email address to your GitHub account
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: GitHub allows you to add as many email addresses to your account as you like. If you set an email address in your local Git configuration, you will need to add it to your account settings in order to connect your commits to your account. For more information about your email address and commits, see "Setting your commit email address."

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Changing your primary email address
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: You can change the email address associated with your personal account at any time.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Verifying your email address
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: Verifying your primary email address ensures strengthened security, allows GitHub staff to better assist you if you forget your password, and gives you access to more features on GitHub.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Setting a backup email address
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: Use a backup email address as an additional destination for security-relevant account notifications and to securely reset your password if you can no longer access your primary email address.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Setting your commit email address
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: You can set the email address that is used to author commits on GitHub.com and on your computer.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Blocking command line pushes that expose your personal email address
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: If you've chosen to keep your email address private when performing web-based operations, you can also choose to block command line pushes that may expose your personal email address.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Remembering your GitHub username or email
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: Are you signing in to GitHub.com for the first time in a while? If so, welcome back! If you can't remember the username for your personal account on GitHub, you can try these methods for remembering it.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Types of emails GitHub sends
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: There are several types of emails you can receive from GitHub, including notifications, account information, customer research invitations, and marketing communications.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Managing marketing emails from GitHub
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: In addition to notifications and account emails, GitHub occasionally sends marketing emails with news and information about our products. If you unsubscribe from existing marketing emails, you won't be included in future campaigns unless you change your GitHub email settings.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Managing access to your personal repositories
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: You can give people collaborator access to repositories owned by your personal account.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Inviting collaborators to a personal repository
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: You can invite users to become collaborators to your personal repository.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Removing a collaborator from a personal repository
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: When you remove a collaborator from your project, they lose read/write access to your repository. If the repository is private and the person has created a fork, then that fork is also deleted.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Removing yourself from a collaborator's repository
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: If you no longer want to be a collaborator on someone else's repository, you can remove yourself.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Maintaining ownership continuity of your personal account's repositories
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: You can invite someone to manage your user owned repositories if you are not able to.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Managing your membership in organizations
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: If you're a member of an organization, you can publicize or hide your membership, view other people's roles, and remove yourself from the organization.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: About organization membership
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: You can become a member of an organization to collaborate with coworkers or open-source contributors across many repositories at once.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Accessing an organization
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: To access an organization that you're a member of, you must sign in to your personal account.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Viewing people's roles in an organization
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: You can view a list of the people in your organization and filter by their role. For more information on organization roles, see "Roles in an organization."

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Requesting organization approval for OAuth apps
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: Organization members and outside collaborators can request that an owner approve access to organization resources for OAuth apps.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Publicizing or hiding organization membership
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: If you'd like to tell the world which organizations you belong to, you can display the avatars of the organizations on your profile.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Managing your scheduled reminders
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: Get reminders in Slack when you or your team have pull requests waiting for review.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Removing yourself from an organization
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: If you're an outside collaborator or a member of an organization, you can leave the organization at any time.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Setting up and managing your GitHub profile
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: You can customize your GitHub profile and manage your contribution graph.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Customizing your profile
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: You can customize your profile so that other people can get a better sense of who you are and the work you do.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: About your profile
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: Your profile page tells people the story of your work through the repositories you're interested in, the contributions you've made, and the conversations you've had.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: About your organization's profile
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: Your organization's profile page shows basic information about your organization.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Personalizing your profile
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: You can share information about yourself with other GitHub users by setting a profile picture and adding a bio to your profile.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Managing your profile README
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: You can add a README to your GitHub profile to tell other people about yourself.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Pinning items to your profile
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: You can pin gists and repositories to your profile so other people can quickly see your best work.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Setting your profile to private
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: A private profile displays only limited information, and hides some activity.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Managing contribution settings on your profile
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: Your contributions, including commits, proposed pull requests, and opened issues, are displayed on your profile so people can easily see the work you've done.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Viewing contributions on your profile
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: Your GitHub profile shows off your pinned repositories, Achievements, and a graph of your repository contributions over the past year.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Showing an overview of your activity on your profile
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: You can enable the activity overview section on your profile to give viewers more context about the types of contributions you make.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Showing your private contributions and achievements on your profile
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: Your GitHub profile shows a graph of your repository contributions over the past year. You can choose to show anonymized activity from private and internal repositories in addition to the activity from public repositories.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Sending enterprise contributions to your GitHub.com profile
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: You can highlight your work on GitHub Enterprise by sending the contribution counts to your GitHub.com profile.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Why are my contributions not showing up on my profile?
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: Learn common reasons that contributions may be missing from your contributions graph.

/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.title: Troubleshooting commits on your timeline
/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-m.intro: You can view details for commits from your profile's timeline. If you don't see commits you expect on your profile or can't find commit details from your profile page, the commit date and the commit author date may be different.

/en/account-and-profile/managing-subscri.title: Managing subscriptions and notifications on GitHub
/en/account-and-profile/managing-subscri.intro: You can specify how to receive notifications, the repositories you are interested in, and the types of activity you want to hear about.

/en/account-and-profile/managing-subscri.title: Setting up notifications
/en/account-and-profile/managing-subscri.intro: To improve the relevance of your notifications and simplify your triaging workflow, set up your notifications to match your priorities.

/en/account-and-profile/managing-subscri.title: About notifications
/en/account-and-profile/managing-subscri.intro: Notifications provide updates about the activity on GitHub.com that you've subscribed to. You can use the notifications inbox to customize, triage, and manage your updates.

/en/account-and-profile/managing-subscri.title: Configuring notifications
/en/account-and-profile/managing-subscri.intro: Choose the type of activity on GitHub that you want to receive notifications for and how you want these updates delivered.

/en/account-and-profile/managing-subscri.title: Viewing and triaging notifications
/en/account-and-profile/managing-subscri.intro: To optimize your notifications workflow, you can customize how you view and triage notifications.

/en/account-and-profile/managing-subscri.title: Managing notifications from your inbox
/en/account-and-profile/managing-subscri.intro: Use your inbox to quickly triage and sync your notifications across email and mobile.

/en/account-and-profile/managing-subscri.title: Triaging a single notification
/en/account-and-profile/managing-subscri.intro: When you review and investigate a single notification, you have several triaging options that are optimized for the detailed notification view.

/en/account-and-profile/managing-subscri.title: Customizing a workflow for triaging your notifications
/en/account-and-profile/managing-subscri.intro: To create an ideal workflow for triaging your notifications, you can adapt and customize these example workflows.

/en/account-and-profile/managing-subscri.title: Managing subscriptions for activity on GitHub
/en/account-and-profile/managing-subscri.intro: To maintain sustainable notification workflows, understand and regularly review your subscriptions.

/en/account-and-profile/managing-subscri.title: Viewing your subscriptions
/en/account-and-profile/managing-subscri.intro: To understand where your notifications are coming from and your notifications volume, we recommend reviewing your subscriptions and watched repositories regularly.

/en/account-and-profile/managing-subscri.title: Managing your subscriptions
/en/account-and-profile/managing-subscri.intro: To help you manage your notifications efficiently, there are several ways to unsubscribe.

/en/authentication.title: Authentication documentation
/en/authentication.intro: Keep your account and data secure with features like two-factor authentication, SSH, and commit signature verification.

/en/authentication/keeping-your-account-.title: Keeping your account and data secure
/en/authentication/keeping-your-account-.intro: To protect your personal information, you should keep both your account on GitHub.com and any associated data secure.

/en/authentication/keeping-your-account-.title: About authentication to GitHub
/en/authentication/keeping-your-account-.intro: You can securely access your account's resources by authenticating to GitHub, using different credentials depending on where you authenticate.

/en/authentication/keeping-your-account-.title: Creating a strong password
/en/authentication/keeping-your-account-.intro: Secure your account on GitHub.com with a strong and unique password using a password manager.

/en/authentication/keeping-your-account-.title: Switching between accounts
/en/authentication/keeping-your-account-.intro: You can stay signed in to multiple GitHub.com accounts and managed user accounts and quickly jump between sessions.

/en/authentication/keeping-your-account-.title: Updating your GitHub access credentials
/en/authentication/keeping-your-account-.intro: GitHub credentials include not only your password, but also the access tokens, SSH keys, and application API tokens you use to communicate with GitHub. Should you have the need, you can reset all of these access credentials yourself.

/en/authentication/keeping-your-account-.title: Managing your personal access tokens
/en/authentication/keeping-your-account-.intro: You can use a personal access token in place of a password when authenticating to GitHub in the command line or with the API.

/en/authentication/keeping-your-account-.title: Reviewing your SSH keys
/en/authentication/keeping-your-account-.intro: To keep your credentials secure, you should regularly audit your SSH keys, deploy keys, and review authorized applications that access your account on GitHub.com.

/en/authentication/keeping-your-account-.title: Reviewing your deploy keys
/en/authentication/keeping-your-account-.intro: You should review deploy keys to ensure that there aren't any unauthorized (or possibly compromised) keys. You can also approve existing deploy keys that are valid.

/en/authentication/keeping-your-account-.title: Token expiration and revocation
/en/authentication/keeping-your-account-.intro: Your tokens can expire and can also be revoked by you, applications you have authorized, and GitHub itself.

/en/authentication/keeping-your-account-.title: Reviewing your security log
/en/authentication/keeping-your-account-.intro: You can review the security log for your personal account to better understand actions you've performed and actions others have performed that involve you.

/en/authentication/keeping-your-account-.title: Security log events
/en/authentication/keeping-your-account-.intro: Learn about security log events recorded for your personal account.

/en/authentication/keeping-your-account-.title: Removing sensitive data from a repository
/en/authentication/keeping-your-account-.intro: If you commit sensitive data, such as a password or SSH key into a Git repository, you can remove it from the history. To entirely remove unwanted files from a repository's history you can use either the git filter-repo tool or the BFG Repo-Cleaner open source tool.

/en/authentication/keeping-your-account-.title: About anonymized URLs
/en/authentication/keeping-your-account-.intro: If you upload an image or video to GitHub, the URL of the image or video will be modified so your information is not trackable.

/en/authentication/keeping-your-account-.title: About GitHub's IP addresses
/en/authentication/keeping-your-account-.intro: GitHub serves applications from multiple IP address ranges, which are available using the API.

/en/authentication/keeping-your-account-.title: GitHub's SSH key fingerprints
/en/authentication/keeping-your-account-.intro: Public key fingerprints can be used to validate a connection to a remote server.

/en/authentication/keeping-your-account-.title: Sudo mode
/en/authentication/keeping-your-account-.intro: To confirm access to your account before you perform a potentially sensitive action, GitHub.com prompts for authentication.

/en/authentication/keeping-your-account-.title: Preventing unauthorized access
/en/authentication/keeping-your-account-.intro: You may be alerted to a security incident in the media, such as the discovery of the Heartbleed bug, or your computer could be stolen while you're signed in to GitHub.com. In such cases, changing your password prevents any unintended future access to your account and projects.

/en/authentication/keeping-your-account-.title: Viewing and managing your sessions
/en/authentication/keeping-your-account-.intro: You can view and revoke your active sessions in your settings.

/en/authentication/securing-your-account.title: Securing your account with two-factor authentication (2FA)
/en/authentication/securing-your-account.intro: You can set up your account on GitHub.com to require an authentication code in addition to your password when you sign in.

/en/authentication/securing-your-account.title: About two-factor authentication
/en/authentication/securing-your-account.intro: Two-factor authentication (2FA) is an extra layer of security used when logging into websites or apps. With 2FA, you have to log in with your username and password and provide another form of authentication that only you know or have access to.

/en/authentication/securing-your-account.title: Configuring two-factor authentication
/en/authentication/securing-your-account.intro: You can choose among multiple options to add a second source of authentication to your account.

/en/authentication/securing-your-account.title: Configuring two-factor authentication recovery methods
/en/authentication/securing-your-account.intro: You can set up a variety of recovery methods to access your account if you lose your two-factor authentication credentials.

/en/authentication/securing-your-account.title: Accessing GitHub using two-factor authentication
/en/authentication/securing-your-account.intro: With 2FA enabled, you'll be asked to provide your 2FA authentication code, as well as your password, when you sign in to GitHub.

/en/authentication/securing-your-account.title: Recovering your account if you lose your 2FA credentials
/en/authentication/securing-your-account.intro: If you lose access to your two-factor authentication credentials, you can use your recovery codes, or another recovery option, to regain access to your account.

/en/authentication/securing-your-account.title: Changing your preferred two-factor authentication method
/en/authentication/securing-your-account.intro: You can switch your preferred two-factor authentication (2FA) method to complete 2FA prompts with the newly selected method.

/en/authentication/securing-your-account.title: About mandatory two-factor authentication
/en/authentication/securing-your-account.intro: Enable mandatory two-factor authentication to secure your account and maintain access to GitHub.com.

/en/authentication/securing-your-account.title: Countries where SMS authentication is supported
/en/authentication/securing-your-account.intro: Because of delivery success rates, GitHub only supports two-factor authentication via SMS for certain countries.

/en/authentication/securing-your-account.title: Disabling two-factor authentication for your personal account
/en/authentication/securing-your-account.intro: If you disable two-factor authentication for your personal account, you may lose access to organizations you belong to.

/en/authentication/authenticating-with-a.title: Authenticating with a passkey
/en/authentication/authenticating-with-a.intro: You can add passkeys to your personal account on GitHub.com so that you can sign in safely and easily, without requiring a password and two-factor authentication. You can also use passkeys when performing a sensitive action (sudo mode), or to authenticate a password reset.

/en/authentication/authenticating-with-a.title: About passkeys
/en/authentication/authenticating-with-a.intro: Passkeys allow you to sign in safely and easily, without requiring a password and two-factor authentication.

/en/authentication/authenticating-with-a.title: Managing your passkeys
/en/authentication/authenticating-with-a.intro: You may be prompted to register a passkey during sign-in, or you can choose to register a new passkey in your account settings. For 2FA users, you can upgrade existing eligible security keys into passkeys.

/en/authentication/authenticating-with-a.title: Signing in with a passkey
/en/authentication/authenticating-with-a.intro: You can use a passkey to sign in safely and easily to GitHub.com, without requiring a password and two-factor authentication. You can also sign in using a passkey on a nearby device.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/authenticati.title: Authenticating with SAML single sign-on
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/authenticati.intro: You can authenticate to GitHub Enterprise Cloud with SAML single sign-on (SSO) and view your active sessions.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/authenticati.title: About authentication with SAML single sign-on
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/authenticati.intro: You can access an organization that uses SAML single sign-on (SSO) by authenticating through an identity provider (IdP).

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/authenticati.title: Authorizing an SSH key for use with SAML single sign-on
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/authenticati.intro: To use an SSH key with an organization that uses SAML single sign-on (SSO), you must first authorize the key.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/authenticati.title: Authorizing a personal access token for use with SAML single sign-on
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/authenticati.intro: To use a personal access token (classic) with an organization that uses SAML single sign-on (SSO), you must first authorize the token.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/authenticati.title: Viewing and managing your active SAML sessions
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/authenticati.intro: You can view and revoke your active SAML sessions in your settings.

/en/authentication/connecting-to-github-.title: Connecting to GitHub with SSH
/en/authentication/connecting-to-github-.intro: You can connect to GitHub using the Secure Shell Protocol (SSH), which provides a secure channel over an unsecured network.

/en/authentication/connecting-to-github-.title: About SSH
/en/authentication/connecting-to-github-.intro: Using the SSH protocol, you can connect and authenticate to remote servers and services. With SSH keys, you can connect to GitHub without supplying your username and personal access token at each visit. You can also use an SSH key to sign commits.

/en/authentication/connecting-to-github-.title: Using SSH agent forwarding
/en/authentication/connecting-to-github-.intro: To simplify deploying to a server, you can set up SSH agent forwarding to securely use local SSH keys.

/en/authentication/connecting-to-github-.title: Managing deploy keys
/en/authentication/connecting-to-github-.intro: Learn different ways to manage SSH keys on your servers when you automate deployment scripts and which way is best for you.

/en/authentication/connecting-to-github-.title: Checking for existing SSH keys
/en/authentication/connecting-to-github-.intro: Before you generate an SSH key, you can check to see if you have any existing SSH keys.

/en/authentication/connecting-to-github-.title: Generating a new SSH key and adding it to the ssh-agent
/en/authentication/connecting-to-github-.intro: After you've checked for existing SSH keys, you can generate a new SSH key to use for authentication, then add it to the ssh-agent.

/en/authentication/connecting-to-github-.title: Adding a new SSH key to your GitHub account
/en/authentication/connecting-to-github-.intro: To configure your account on GitHub.com to use your new (or existing) SSH key, you'll also need to add the key to your account.

/en/authentication/connecting-to-github-.title: Testing your SSH connection
/en/authentication/connecting-to-github-.intro: After you've set up your SSH key and added it to your account on GitHub.com, you can test your connection.

/en/authentication/connecting-to-github-.title: Working with SSH key passphrases
/en/authentication/connecting-to-github-.intro: You can secure your SSH keys and configure an authentication agent so that you won't have to reenter your passphrase every time you use your SSH keys.

/en/authentication/troubleshooting-ssh.title: Troubleshooting SSH
/en/authentication/troubleshooting-ssh.intro: When using SSH to connect and authenticate to GitHub, you may need to troubleshoot unexpected issues that may arise.

/en/authentication/troubleshooting-ssh/u.title: Using SSH over the HTTPS port
/en/authentication/troubleshooting-ssh/u.intro: Sometimes, firewalls refuse to allow SSH connections entirely.  If using HTTPS cloning with credential caching is not an option, you can attempt to clone using an SSH connection made over the HTTPS port.  Most firewall rules should allow this, but proxy servers may interfere.

/en/authentication/troubleshooting-ssh/r.title: Recovering your SSH key passphrase
/en/authentication/troubleshooting-ssh/r.intro: If you've lost your SSH key passphrase, depending on the operating system you use, you may either recover it or you may need to generate a new SSH key passphrase.

/en/authentication/troubleshooting-ssh/d.title: Deleted or missing SSH keys
/en/authentication/troubleshooting-ssh/d.intro: As a security precaution, GitHub automatically deletes SSH keys that haven't been used in a year.

/en/authentication/troubleshooting-ssh/e.title: Error: Host key verification failed
/en/authentication/troubleshooting-ssh/e.intro: As a security precaution, SSH keeps track of which hosts it has previously seen.

/en/authentication/troubleshooting-ssh/e.title: Error: Permission denied (publickey)
/en/authentication/troubleshooting-ssh/e.intro: A "Permission denied" error means that the server rejected your connection. There could be several reasons why, and the most common examples are explained below.

/en/authentication/troubleshooting-ssh/e.title: Error: Bad file number
/en/authentication/troubleshooting-ssh/e.intro: This error usually means you were unable to connect to the server. Often this is caused by firewalls and proxy servers.

/en/authentication/troubleshooting-ssh/e.title: Error: Key already in use
/en/authentication/troubleshooting-ssh/e.intro: This error occurs when you try to add a key that's already been added to another account or repository.

/en/authentication/troubleshooting-ssh/e.title: Error: Permission to user/repo denied to other-user
/en/authentication/troubleshooting-ssh/e.intro: This error means the key you are pushing with is attached to an account which does not have access to the repository.

/en/authentication/troubleshooting-ssh/e.title: Error: Permission to user/repo denied to user/other-repo
/en/authentication/troubleshooting-ssh/e.intro: This error means the key you are pushing with is attached to another repository as a deploy key, and does not have access to the repository you are trying to push to.

/en/authentication/troubleshooting-ssh/e.title: Error: Agent admitted failure to sign
/en/authentication/troubleshooting-ssh/e.intro: In rare circumstances, connecting to GitHub via SSH on Linux produces the error "Agent admitted failure to sign using the key". Follow these steps to resolve the problem.

/en/authentication/troubleshooting-ssh/e.title: Error: ssh-add: illegal option -- apple-use-keychain
/en/authentication/troubleshooting-ssh/e.intro: This error means your version of ssh-add does not support macOS keychain integration, which allows you to store your passphrase in the keychain.

/en/authentication/troubleshooting-ssh/e.title: Error: SSL certificate problem, verify that the CA cert is OK
/en/authentication/troubleshooting-ssh/e.intro: This error means your CA root certificate is out of date. If your CA root certificate needs to be updated, you won't be able to push or pull from GitHub repositories.

/en/authentication/troubleshooting-ssh/e.title: Error: Unknown key type
/en/authentication/troubleshooting-ssh/e.intro: This error means that the SSH key type you used was unrecognized or is unsupported by your SSH client.

/en/authentication/troubleshooting-ssh/e.title: Error: We're doing an SSH key audit
/en/authentication/troubleshooting-ssh/e.intro: This error means the SSH key you're using to perform a Git operation is unverified.

/en/authentication/managing-commit-signa.title: Managing commit signature verification
/en/authentication/managing-commit-signa.intro: GitHub will verify GPG, SSH, or S/MIME signatures so other people will know that your commits come from a trusted source. GitHub will automatically sign commits you make using the GitHub web interface.

/en/authentication/managing-commit-signa.title: About commit signature verification
/en/authentication/managing-commit-signa.intro: Using GPG, SSH, or S/MIME, you can sign tags and commits locally. These tags or commits are marked as verified on GitHub so other people can be confident that the changes come from a trusted source.

/en/authentication/managing-commit-signa.title: Displaying verification statuses for all of your commits
/en/authentication/managing-commit-signa.intro: You can enable vigilant mode for commit signature verification to mark all of your commits and tags with a signature verification status.

/en/authentication/managing-commit-signa.title: Checking for existing GPG keys
/en/authentication/managing-commit-signa.intro: Before you generate a GPG key, you can check to see if you have any existing GPG keys.

/en/authentication/managing-commit-signa.title: Generating a new GPG key
/en/authentication/managing-commit-signa.intro: If you don't have an existing GPG key, you can generate a new GPG key to use for signing commits and tags.

/en/authentication/managing-commit-signa.title: Adding a GPG key to your GitHub account
/en/authentication/managing-commit-signa.intro: To configure your account on GitHub.com to use your new (or existing) GPG key, you'll also need to add the key to your account.

/en/authentication/managing-commit-signa.title: Telling Git about your signing key
/en/authentication/managing-commit-signa.intro: To sign commits locally, you need to inform Git that there's a GPG, SSH, or X.509 key you'd like to use.

/en/authentication/managing-commit-signa.title: Associating an email with your GPG key
/en/authentication/managing-commit-signa.intro: Your GPG key must be associated with a GitHub verified email that matches your committer identity.

/en/authentication/managing-commit-signa.title: Signing commits
/en/authentication/managing-commit-signa.intro: You can sign commits locally using GPG, SSH, or S/MIME.

/en/authentication/managing-commit-signa.title: Signing tags
/en/authentication/managing-commit-signa.intro: You can sign tags locally using GPG, SSH, or S/MIME.

/en/authentication/troubleshooting-commi.title: Troubleshooting commit signature verification
/en/authentication/troubleshooting-commi.intro: You may need to troubleshoot unexpected issues that arise when signing commits locally for verification on GitHub.

/en/authentication/troubleshooting-commi.title: Checking your commit and tag signature verification status
/en/authentication/troubleshooting-commi.intro: You can check the verification status of your commit and tag signatures on GitHub.

/en/authentication/troubleshooting-commi.title: Using a verified email address in your GPG key
/en/authentication/troubleshooting-commi.intro: When verifying a signature, GitHub checks that the committer or tagger email address matches an email address from the GPG key's identities and is a verified email address on the user's account. This ensures that the key belongs to you and that you created the commit or tag.

/en/repositories.title: Repositories documentation
/en/repositories.intro: Learn to use and manage the repositories that allow you to store and collaborate on your project's code.

/en/repositories/creating-and-managing-r.title: Creating and managing repositories
/en/repositories/creating-and-managing-r.intro: You can create a repository on GitHub to store and collaborate on your project's files, then manage the repository's name and location.

/en/repositories/creating-and-managing-r.title: About repositories
/en/repositories/creating-and-managing-r.intro: A repository contains all of your code, your files, and each file's revision history. You can discuss and manage your work within the repository.

/en/repositories/creating-and-managing-r.title: Best practices for repositories
/en/repositories/creating-and-managing-r.intro: Learn how to use repositories most effectively.

/en/repositories/creating-and-managing-r.title: Quickstart for repositories
/en/repositories/creating-and-managing-r.intro: Learn how to create a new repository and commit your first change in 5 minutes.

/en/repositories/creating-and-managing-r.title: Creating a new repository
/en/repositories/creating-and-managing-r.intro: You can create a new repository on your personal account or any organization where you have sufficient permissions.

/en/repositories/creating-and-managing-r.title: Creating a repository from a template
/en/repositories/creating-and-managing-r.intro: You can generate a new repository with the same directory structure and files as an existing repository.

/en/repositories/creating-and-managing-r.title: Creating a template repository
/en/repositories/creating-and-managing-r.intro: You can make an existing repository a template, so you and others can generate new repositories with the same directory structure, branches, and files.

/en/repositories/creating-and-managing-r.title: Creating an issues-only repository
/en/repositories/creating-and-managing-r.intro: GitHub does not provide issues-only access permissions, but you can accomplish this using a second repository which contains only the issues.

/en/repositories/creating-and-managing-r.title: Duplicating a repository
/en/repositories/creating-and-managing-r.intro: To maintain a mirror of a repository without forking it, you can run a special clone command, then mirror-push to the new repository.

/en/repositories/creating-and-managing-r.title: Cloning a repository
/en/repositories/creating-and-managing-r.intro: When you create a repository on GitHub.com, it exists as a remote repository. You can clone your repository to create a local copy on your computer and sync between the two locations.

/en/repositories/creating-and-managing-r.title: Troubleshooting cloning errors
/en/repositories/creating-and-managing-r.intro: If you're having trouble cloning a repository, check these common errors.

/en/repositories/creating-and-managing-r.title: Renaming a repository
/en/repositories/creating-and-managing-r.intro: You can rename a repository if you're either an organization owner or have admin permissions for the repository.

/en/repositories/creating-and-managing-r.title: Transferring a repository
/en/repositories/creating-and-managing-r.intro: You can transfer repositories to other users or organization accounts.

/en/repositories/creating-and-managing-r.title: Deleting a repository
/en/repositories/creating-and-managing-r.intro: You can delete any repository or fork if you're either an organization owner or have admin permissions for the repository or fork. Deleting a forked repository does not delete the upstream repository.

/en/repositories/creating-and-managing-r.title: Restoring a deleted repository
/en/repositories/creating-and-managing-r.intro: You can restore some deleted repositories to recover their contents.

/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.title: Managing your repository’s settings and features
/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.intro: You can customize your repository, enable or disable optional features for your repository, and manage your repository’s settings.

/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.title: Customizing your repository
/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.intro: You can choose the way your repository appears by customizing your repository.

/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.title: About READMEs
/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.intro: You can add a README file to your repository to tell other people why your project is useful, what they can do with your project, and how they can use it.

/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.title: Licensing a repository
/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.intro: Public repositories on GitHub are often used to share open source software. For your repository to truly be open source, you'll need to license it so that others are free to use, change, and distribute the software.

/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.title: Displaying a sponsor button in your repository
/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.intro: You can add a sponsor button in your repository to increase the visibility of funding options for your open source project.

/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.title: Customizing your repository's social media preview
/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.intro: You can customize the image displayed on social media platforms when someone links to your repository.

/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.title: Classifying your repository with topics
/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.intro: To help other people find and contribute to your project, you can add topics to your repository related to your project's intended purpose, subject area, affinity groups, or other important qualities.

/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.title: About code owners
/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.intro: You can use a CODEOWNERS file to define individuals or teams that are responsible for code in a repository.

/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.title: About repository languages
/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.intro: The files and directories within a repository determine the languages that make up the repository. You can view a repository's languages to get a quick overview of the repository.

/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.title: About CITATION files
/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.intro: You can add a CITATION file to your repository to help users correctly cite your software.

/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.title: Enabling features for your repository
/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.intro: You can enable, configure, and disable optional features for your repository.

/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.title: Disabling issues
/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.intro: You may wish to turn issues off for your repository if you do not accept contributions or bug reports.

/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.title: Disabling projects in a repository
/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.intro: Repository administrators can turn off projects and classic projects for a repository if you or your team choose not to use projects.

/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.title: Managing GitHub Actions settings for a repository
/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.intro: You can disable or configure GitHub Actions for a specific repository.

/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.title: Enabling or disabling GitHub Discussions for a repository
/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.intro: You can use GitHub Discussions in a repository as a place for your community to have conversations, ask questions, and post answers without scoping work in an issue.

/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.title: Managing security and analysis settings for your repository
/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.intro: You can control features that secure and analyze the code in your project on GitHub.

/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.title: Managing repository settings
/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.intro: You can choose the way your repository functions by managing repository settings.

/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.title: Setting repository visibility
/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.intro: You can choose who can view your repository.

/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.title: Managing teams and people with access to your repository
/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.intro: You can see everyone who has access to your repository and adjust permissions.

/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.title: Managing the forking policy for your repository
/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.intro: You can allow or prevent the forking of a specific private repository owned by an organization.

/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.title: Managing pull request reviews in your repository
/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.intro: You can limit which users can approve or request changes to a pull requests in a public repository.

/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.title: Managing the commit signoff policy for your repository
/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.intro: You can require users to automatically sign off on the commits they make to your repository using GitHub's web interface.

/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.title: Managing the push policy for your repository
/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.intro: You can limit how many branches and tags can be updated in a single push.

/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.title: Managing Git LFS objects in archives of your repository
/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.intro: You can choose whether Git Large File Storage (Git LFS) objects are included in source code archives, such as ZIP files and tarballs, GitHub creates for your repository.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/repositories/.title: Enabling anonymous Git read access for a repository
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/repositories/.intro: As a repository administrator, you can enable or disable anonymous Git read access for public repositories that meet certain requirements.

/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.title: About email notifications for pushes to your repository
/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.intro: You can choose to automatically send email notifications to a specific email address when anyone pushes to the repository.

/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.title: Configuring autolinks to reference external resources
/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.intro: You can add autolinks to external resources like JIRA issues and Zendesk tickets to help streamline your workflow.

/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.title: Configuring tag protection rules
/en/repositories/managing-your-repositor.intro: You can configure tag protection rules for your repository to prevent contributors from creating or deleting tags.

/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.title: Configuring branches and merges in your repository
/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.intro: You can manage branches in your repository, configure the way branches are merged in your repository, and protect important branches by defining the mergeability of pull requests.

/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.title: Managing branches in your repository
/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.intro: Whenever you propose a change in Git, you create a new branch. Branch management is an important part of the Git workflow. After some time, your list of branches may grow, so it's a good idea to delete merged or stale branches.

/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.title: Viewing branches in your repository
/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.intro: Branches are central to collaboration on GitHub, and the best way to view them is the branches page.

/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.title: Renaming a branch
/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.intro: You can change the name of a branch in a repository.

/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.title: Changing the default branch
/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.intro: If you have more than one branch in your repository, you can configure any branch as the default branch.

/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.title: Deleting and restoring branches in a pull request
/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.intro: If you have write access in a repository, you can delete branches that are associated with closed or merged pull requests. You cannot delete branches that are associated with open pull requests.

/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.title: Configuring pull request merges
/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.intro: You can configure pull request merges on GitHub.com to match your workflow and preferences for managing Git history.

/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.title: About merge methods on GitHub
/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.intro: You can allow contributors with push access to your repository to merge their pull requests on GitHub.com with different merge options or enforce a specific merge method for all of your repository's pull requests.

/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.title: Configuring commit merging for pull requests
/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.intro: You can enforce, allow, or disable merging with a merge commit for all pull request merges on GitHub.com in your repository.

/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.title: Configuring commit squashing for pull requests
/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.intro: You can enforce, allow, or disable commit squashing for all pull request merges on GitHub.com in your repository.

/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.title: Configuring commit rebasing for pull requests
/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.intro: You can enforce, allow, or disable commit rebasing for all pull request merges on GitHub.com in your repository.

/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.title: Managing a merge queue
/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.intro: You can increase development velocity with a merge queue for pull requests in your repository.

/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.title: Managing suggestions to update pull request branches
/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.intro: You can give users the ability to always update a pull request branch when it is not up to date with the base branch.

/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.title: Managing auto-merge for pull requests in your repository
/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.intro: You can allow or disallow auto-merge for pull requests in your repository.

/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.title: Managing the automatic deletion of branches
/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.intro: You can have head branches automatically deleted after pull requests are merged in your repository.

/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.title: Managing protected branches
/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.intro: You can set up rules to protect certain branches in your repository. For example, you can block pull requests that don't pass status checks or require that pull requests have a specific number of approving reviews before they can be merged.

/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.title: About protected branches
/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.intro: You can protect important branches by setting branch protection rules, which define whether collaborators can delete or force push to the branch and set requirements for any pushes to the branch, such as passing status checks or a linear commit history.

/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.title: Managing a branch protection rule
/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.intro: You can create a branch protection rule to enforce certain workflows for one or more branches, such as requiring an approving review or passing status checks for all pull requests merged into the protected branch.

/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.title: Managing rulesets for a repository
/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.intro: Rulesets help you to control how people can interact with branches and tags in a repository.

/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.title: About rulesets
/en/repositories/configuring-branches-an.intro: Rulesets help you to control how people can interact with branches and tags in a repository.
