/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/organization.title: Accessing your organization if your identity provider is unavailable
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/organization.intro: Organization owners can sign into GitHub Enterprise Cloud even if their identity provider is unavailable by bypassing single sign-on (SSO) and using their recovery codes.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/organization.title: Troubleshooting identity and access management for your organization
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/organization.intro: Review and resolve common troubleshooting errors for managing your organization's SAML SSO, team synchronization, or identity provider (IdP) connection.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/organization.title: Granting access to your organization with SAML single sign-on
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/organization.intro: Organization owners can grant access to their organization with SAML single sign-on. This access can be granted to organization members, bots, and service accounts.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/organization.title: Managing bots and service accounts with SAML single sign-on
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/organization.intro: Organizations that have enabled SAML single sign-on can retain access for bots and service accounts.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/organization.title: Viewing and managing a member's SAML access to your organization
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/organization.intro: You can view and revoke an organization member's linked identity, active sessions, and authorized credentials.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/organization.title: About two-factor authentication and SAML single sign-on
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/organization.intro: Organization owners can enable both SAML single sign-on and two-factor authentication to add additional authentication measures for their organization members.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/organization.title: Managing Git access to your organization's repositories
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/organization.intro: You can add an SSH certificate authority (CA) to your organization and allow members to access the organization's repositories over Git using keys signed by the SSH CA.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/organization.title: About SSH certificate authorities
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/organization.intro: With an SSH certificate authority, your organization or enterprise account can provide SSH certificates that members can use to access your resources with Git.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/organization.title: Managing your organization's SSH certificate authorities
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/organization.intro: You can add or delete SSH certificate authorities from your organization.

/en/organizations/migrating-to-improved-.title: Migrating to improved organization permissions
/en/organizations/migrating-to-improved-.intro: If your organization was created after September 2015, your organization includes improved organization permissions by default. Organizations created before September 2015 may need to migrate older Owners and Admin teams to the improved organization permissions model.

/en/organizations/migrating-to-improved-.title: Converting an Owners team to improved organization permissions
/en/organizations/migrating-to-improved-.intro: If your organization was created after September 2015, your organization has improved organization permissions by default. Organizations created before September 2015 may need to migrate older Owners and Admin teams to the improved permissions model. The "Owner" is now an administrative role given to individual members of your organization. Members of your legacy Owners team are automatically given owner privileges.

/en/organizations/migrating-to-improved-.title: Converting an admin team to improved organization permissions
/en/organizations/migrating-to-improved-.intro: If your organization was created after September 2015, your organization has improved organization permissions by default. Organizations created before September 2015 may need to migrate older Owners and Admin teams to the improved permissions model. Members of legacy admin teams automatically retain the ability to create repositories until those teams are migrated to the improved organization permissions model.

/en/organizations/migrating-to-improved-.title: Migrating admin teams to improved organization permissions
/en/organizations/migrating-to-improved-.intro: If your organization was created after September 2015, your organization has improved organization permissions by default. Organizations created before September 2015 may need to migrate older Owners and Admin teams to the improved permissions model. Members of legacy admin teams automatically retain the ability to create repositories until those teams are migrated to the improved organization permissions model.

/en/code-security.title: Code security documentation
/en/code-security.intro: Build security into your GitHub workflow with features to keep secrets and vulnerabilities out of your codebase, and to maintain your software supply chain.

/en/code-security/getting-started.title: Getting started with code security
/en/code-security/getting-started.intro: Introduction to code security with GitHub.

/en/code-security/getting-started/github.title: GitHub security features
/en/code-security/getting-started/github.intro: An overview of GitHub security features.

/en/code-security/getting-started/depend.title: Dependabot quickstart guide
/en/code-security/getting-started/depend.intro: You can use Dependabot to alert you when your repository is using a software dependency with a known vulnerability. This guide will help get you started on enabling Dependabot for a repository, and exploring reported alerts.

/en/code-security/getting-started/securi.title: Securing your repository
/en/code-security/getting-started/securi.intro: You can use a number of GitHub features to help keep your repository secure.

/en/code-security/getting-started/securi.title: Securing your organization
/en/code-security/getting-started/securi.intro: You can use a number of GitHub features to help keep your organization secure.

/en/code-security/getting-started/adding.title: Adding a security policy to your repository
/en/code-security/getting-started/adding.intro: You can give instructions for how to report a security vulnerability in your project by adding a security policy to your repository.

/en/code-security/getting-started/auditi.title: Auditing security alerts
/en/code-security/getting-started/auditi.intro: GitHub provides a variety of tools you can use to audit and monitor actions taken in response to security alerts.

/en/code-security/getting-started/best-p.title: Best practices for preventing data leaks in your organization
/en/code-security/getting-started/best-p.intro: Learn guidance and recommendations to help you avoid private or sensitive data present in your organization from being exposed.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/code-securit.title: Adopting GitHub Advanced Security at scale
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/code-securit.intro: A phased approach to rolling out GitHub Advanced Security at your company using industry and GitHub best practices.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/code-securit.title: Introduction to adopting GitHub Advanced Security at scale
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/code-securit.intro: You can adopt GitHub Advanced Security at scale in your company following industry and GitHub best practices.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/code-securit.title: Phase 1: Align on your rollout strategy and goals
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/code-securit.intro: Before enabling code scanning and secret scanning, plan how GHAS should be rolled out across your enterprise.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/code-securit.title: Phase 2: Preparing to enable at scale
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/code-securit.intro: In this phase you will prepare developers and collect data about your repositories to ensure your teams are ready and you have everything you need for pilot programs and rolling out code scanning and secret scanning.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/code-securit.title: Phase 3: Pilot programs
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/code-securit.intro: You may benefit from beginning with a few high-impact projects and teams with which to pilot an initial rollout. This will allow an initial group within your company to get familiar with GHAS, learn how to enable and configure GHAS, and build a solid foundation on GHAS before rolling out to the remainder of your company.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/code-securit.title: Phase 4: Create internal documentation
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/code-securit.intro: You will create internal documentation and then communicate this to the consumers of GitHub Advanced Security.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/code-securit.title: Phase 5: Rollout and scale code scanning
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/code-securit.intro: You can leverage the available APIs to rollout code scanning programmatically by team and by language across your enterprise using the repository data you collected earlier.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/code-securit.title: Phase 6: Rollout and scale secret scanning
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/code-securit.intro: For the final phase, you will focus on the rollout of secret scanning. Secret scanning is a more straightforward tool to rollout than code scanning, as it involves less configuration, but it's critical to have a strategy for handling new and old results.

/en/code-security/secret-scanning.title: Keeping secrets secure with secret scanning
/en/code-security/secret-scanning.intro: Let GitHub do the hard work of ensuring that tokens, private keys, and other code secrets are not exposed in your repository.

/en/code-security/secret-scanning/about-.title: About secret scanning
/en/code-security/secret-scanning/about-.intro: GitHub scans repositories for known types of secrets, to prevent fraudulent use of secrets that were committed accidentally.

/en/code-security/secret-scanning/secret.title: Secret scanning partner program
/en/code-security/secret-scanning/secret.intro: As a service provider, you can partner with GitHub to have your secret token formats secured through secret scanning, which searches for accidental commits of your secret format and can be sent to a service provider's verify endpoint.

/en/code-security/secret-scanning/config.title: Configuring secret scanning for your repositories
/en/code-security/secret-scanning/config.intro: You can configure how GitHub scans your repositories for leaked secrets and generates alerts.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/code-securit.title: Defining custom patterns for secret scanning
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/code-securit.intro: You can define your own custom patterns to extend the capabilities of secret scanning by generating one or more regular expressions.

/en/code-security/secret-scanning/about-.title: About the regular expression generator for custom patterns
/en/code-security/secret-scanning/about-.intro: You can define your own custom patterns to extend the capabilities of secret scanning by generating one or more regular expressions for each pattern, using the regular expression generator.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/code-securit.title: Generating regular expressions for custom patterns with AI
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/code-securit.intro: You can use the regular expression generator to generate regular expressions for custom patterns. The generator uses an AI model to generate expressions that match your input, and optionally example strings.

/en/code-security/secret-scanning/managi.title: Managing alerts from secret scanning
/en/code-security/secret-scanning/managi.intro: You can view and close alerts for secrets checked in to your repository.

/en/code-security/secret-scanning/secret.title: Secret scanning patterns
/en/code-security/secret-scanning/secret.intro: Lists of supported secrets and the partners that GitHub works with to prevent fraudulent use of secrets that were committed accidentally.

/en/code-security/secret-scanning/about-.title: About the detection of generic secrets with secret scanning
/en/code-security/secret-scanning/about-.intro: Learn how secret scanning uses AI to scan and create alerts for unstructured secrets, such as passwords.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/code-securit.title: Enabling AI-powered generic secret detection
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/code-securit.intro: You can enable AI-powered generic secret detection for your repository. Alerts for generic secrets, such as passwords, are displayed in a separate list on the secret scanning alerts page.

/en/code-security/secret-scanning/push-p.title: Push protection for repositories and organizations
/en/code-security/secret-scanning/push-p.intro: You can use secret scanning to prevent supported secrets from being pushed into your  organization or repository by enabling push protection.

/en/code-security/secret-scanning/push-p.title: Push protection for users
/en/code-security/secret-scanning/push-p.intro: You can use secret scanning to block commits containing secrets in any public repository by enabling push protection for yourself.

/en/code-security/secret-scanning/pushin.title: Pushing a branch blocked by push protection
/en/code-security/secret-scanning/pushin.intro: The push protection feature of secret scanning proactively protects you against leaked secrets in your repositories. You can resolve blocked pushes and, once the detected secret is removed, you can push changes to your working branch from the command line or the web UI.

/en/code-security/secret-scanning/troubl.title: Troubleshooting secret scanning
/en/code-security/secret-scanning/troubl.intro: If you have problems with secret scanning, you can use these tips to help resolve issues.

/en/code-security/code-scanning.title: Finding security vulnerabilities and errors in your code with code scanning
/en/code-security/code-scanning.intro: Keep your code secure by using code scanning to identify and fix potential security vulnerabilities and other errors in your code.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/introduc.title: Introduction to code scanning
/en/code-security/code-scanning/introduc.intro: Learn what code scanning is, how it helps you secure your code, and what code scanning tools are available.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/introduc.title: About code scanning
/en/code-security/code-scanning/introduc.intro: You can use code scanning to find security vulnerabilities and errors in the code for your project on GitHub.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/introduc.title: About code scanning with CodeQL
/en/code-security/code-scanning/introduc.intro: You can use CodeQL to identify vulnerabilities and errors in your code. The results are shown as code scanning alerts in GitHub.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/enabling.title: Enabling code scanning
/en/code-security/code-scanning/enabling.intro: You can quickly and easily secure your code with default setup for code scanning.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/enabling.title: Configuring default setup for code scanning
/en/code-security/code-scanning/enabling.intro: You can quickly secure code in your repository with default setup for code scanning.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/enabling.title: Evaluating default setup for code scanning
/en/code-security/code-scanning/enabling.intro: Learn how to assess how code scanning is working for you, and how you can customize your setup to best meet your code security needs.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/enabling.title: Configuring default setup for code scanning at scale
/en/code-security/code-scanning/enabling.intro: You can quickly configure code scanning for repositories across your organization using default setup.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/creating.title: Creating an advanced setup for code scanning
/en/code-security/code-scanning/creating.intro: For more granular control over your code scanning configuration, you can secure your code with advanced setup for code scanning.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/creating.title: Configuring advanced setup for code scanning
/en/code-security/code-scanning/creating.intro: You can configure advanced setup for a repository to find security vulnerabilities in your code using a highly customizable code scanning configuration.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/creating.title: Customizing your advanced setup for code scanning
/en/code-security/code-scanning/creating.intro: You can customize how your advanced setup scans the code in your project for vulnerabilities and errors.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/creating.title: CodeQL code scanning for compiled languages
/en/code-security/code-scanning/creating.intro: Understand the autobuild method CodeQL analysis uses to build code for compiled languages and learn how you can customize the build command if you need to.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/creating.title: Configuring advanced setup for code scanning with CodeQL at scale
/en/code-security/code-scanning/creating.intro: You can use a script to configure advanced setup for code scanning for a specific group of repositories in your organization.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/creating.title: Recommended hardware resources for running CodeQL
/en/code-security/code-scanning/creating.intro: Recommended specifications (RAM, CPU cores, and disk) for running CodeQL analysis on self-hosted machines, based on the size of your codebase.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/creating.title: Running CodeQL code scanning in a container
/en/code-security/code-scanning/creating.intro: You can run code scanning in a container by ensuring that all processes run in the same container.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/managing.title: Managing code scanning alerts
/en/code-security/code-scanning/managing.intro: Learn how to triage, track, and resolve code scanning alerts.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/managing.title: About code scanning alerts
/en/code-security/code-scanning/managing.intro: Learn about the different types of code scanning alerts and the information that helps you understand the problem each alert highlights.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/managing.title: About autofix for CodeQL code scanning
/en/code-security/code-scanning/managing.intro: Learn how GitHub uses AI to suggest potential fixes for code scanning alerts found by CodeQL in your pull request.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/managing.title: Managing code scanning alerts for your repository
/en/code-security/code-scanning/managing.intro: From the security view, you can view, fix, or dismiss alerts for potential vulnerabilities or errors in your project's code.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/managing.title: Triaging code scanning alerts in pull requests
/en/code-security/code-scanning/managing.intro: When code scanning identifies a problem in a pull request, you can review the highlighted code and resolve the alert.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/managing.title: Tracking code scanning alerts in issues using task lists
/en/code-security/code-scanning/managing.intro: You can add code scanning alerts to issues using task lists. This makes it easy to create a plan for development work that includes fixing alerts.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/managing.title: Managing your code scanning configuration
/en/code-security/code-scanning/managing.intro: You can manage your existing code scanning configuration with the help of metrics and logging outputs generated by your analysis.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/managing.title: About the tool status page for code scanning
/en/code-security/code-scanning/managing.intro: The tool status page shows useful information about all of your code scanning tools. If code scanning is not working as you'd expect, the tool status page is a good starting point for debugging problems.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/managing.title: Editing your configuration of default setup
/en/code-security/code-scanning/managing.intro: You can edit your existing configuration of default setup for code scanning to better meet your code security needs.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/managing.title: CodeQL query suites
/en/code-security/code-scanning/managing.intro: You can choose from different built-in CodeQL query suites to use in your CodeQL code scanning setup.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/managing.title: Configuring larger runners for default setup
/en/code-security/code-scanning/managing.intro: You can run code scanning default setup more quickly on bigger codebases using larger runners.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/managing.title: Viewing code scanning logs
/en/code-security/code-scanning/managing.intro: You can view the output generated during code scanning analysis in GitHub.com.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/managing.title: C and C++ queries for CodeQL analysis
/en/code-security/code-scanning/managing.intro: Explore the queries that CodeQL uses to analyze code written in C or C++ when you select the default or the security-extended query suite.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/managing.title: C# queries for CodeQL analysis
/en/code-security/code-scanning/managing.intro: Explore the queries that CodeQL uses to analyze code written in C# when you select the default or the security-extended query suite.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/managing.title: Go queries for CodeQL analysis
/en/code-security/code-scanning/managing.intro: Explore the queries that CodeQL uses to analyze code written in Go (Golang) when you select the default or the security-extended query suite.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/managing.title: Java and Kotlin queries for CodeQL analysis
/en/code-security/code-scanning/managing.intro: Explore the queries that CodeQL uses to analyze code written in Java or Kotlin when you select the default or the security-extended query suite.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/managing.title: JavaScript and TypeScript queries for CodeQL analysis
/en/code-security/code-scanning/managing.intro: Explore the queries that CodeQL uses to analyze code written in JavaScript or TypeScript when you select the default or the security-extended query suite.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/managing.title: Python queries for CodeQL analysis
/en/code-security/code-scanning/managing.intro: Explore the queries that CodeQL uses to analyze code written in Python when you select the default or the security-extended query suite.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/managing.title: Ruby queries for CodeQL analysis
/en/code-security/code-scanning/managing.intro: Explore the queries that CodeQL uses to analyze code written in Ruby when you select the default or the security-extended query suite.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/managing.title: Swift queries for CodeQL analysis
/en/code-security/code-scanning/managing.intro: Explore the queries that CodeQL uses to analyze code written in Swift when you select the default or the security-extended query suite.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/integrat.title: Integrating with code scanning
/en/code-security/code-scanning/integrat.intro: You can integrate third-party code analysis tools with GitHub code scanning by uploading data as SARIF files.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/integrat.title: About integration with code scanning
/en/code-security/code-scanning/integrat.intro: You can perform code scanning externally and then display the results in GitHub, or configure webhooks that listen to code scanning activity in your repository.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/integrat.title: Using code scanning with your existing CI system
/en/code-security/code-scanning/integrat.intro: You can analyze your code with the CodeQL CLI or another tool in a third-party continuous integration system and upload the results to GitHub.com. The resulting code scanning alerts are shown alongside any alerts generated within GitHub.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/integrat.title: Uploading a SARIF file to GitHub
/en/code-security/code-scanning/integrat.intro: You can upload SARIF files generated outside GitHub and see code scanning alerts from third-party tools in your repository.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/integrat.title: SARIF support for code scanning
/en/code-security/code-scanning/integrat.intro: To display results from a third-party static analysis tool in your repository on GitHub, you'll need your results stored in a SARIF file that supports a specific subset of the SARIF 2.1.0 JSON schema for code scanning. If you use the default CodeQL static analysis engine, then your results will display in your repository on GitHub automatically.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.title: Troubleshooting code scanning
/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.intro: When analyzing your code with code scanning, you may need to troubleshoot unexpected issues.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.title: Error: "Advanced Security must be enabled for this repository to use code scanning"
/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.intro: If you see this error, make sure that GitHub Advanced Security is enabled.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.title: Alerts found in generated code
/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.intro: When analyzing your code with code scanning, you may wish to build only the code which you wish to analyze.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.title: Code scanning analysis takes too long
/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.intro: You can fine tune your code scanning configuration to minimize analysis time.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.title: Automatic build failed for a compiled language
/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.intro: If automatic build fails, you can configure code scanning to use specific build steps for compiled languages.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.title: Cannot enable CodeQL in a private repository
/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.intro: GitHub Advanced Security must be enabled in order to use code scanning on private repositories.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/code-security.title: A particular language is causing default setup to fail
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/code-security.intro: When you enable default setup, all languages selected for analysis must be successfully analyzed, or the configuration of default setup will fail.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.title: Enabling default setup takes too long
/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.intro: If you think that enabling default setup has stalled, you can restart the process.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.title: Extraction errors in the database
/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.intro: You can check whether or not extraction errors affect the health of the CodeQL database created.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.title: CodeQL scanned fewer lines than expected
/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.intro: If CodeQL analyzed less code than you expected, you may need to use a custom build command.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.title: Logs are not detailed enough
/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.intro: If you'd like to increase the level of detail in your logs, try these steps.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.title: Error: "No source code was seen during the build"
/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.intro: When CodeQL fails to find any source code, you need to resolve this problem to unblock code scanning analysis.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.title: Error: "is not a .ql file, .qls file, a directory, or a query pack specification"
/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.intro: CodeQL was unable to locate one of the queries or sets of queries that are specified for analysis.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.title: Error: "Out of disk" or Error: "Out of memory"
/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.intro: If you see one of these errors with GitHub Actions, you can try alternative runners.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.title: Error: 403 "Resource not accessible by integration"
/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.intro: This error may be seen on pull requests created by Dependabot and can be resolved in a couple of different ways.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.title: Results are different than expected
/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.intro: If your code scanning results are different than you expected, you can check which configurations are active.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.title: Results differ between platforms
/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.intro: You may see different results depending on whether you run the CodeQL analysis workflow on Linux, macOS, or Windows.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.title: Error: "Server error"
/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.intro: If you see this error, it may be transient. Check the current GitHub Actions service status, and try running your workflow again.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.title: Some languages were not analyzed with CodeQL advanced setup
/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.intro: If some languages were not analyzed, you can modify your code scanning workflow to add a matrix specifying the languages you want to analyze.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.title: Two CodeQL workflows
/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.intro: If you see two workflows named "CodeQL", one workflow may be a pre-existing CodeQL workflow file which has been disabled by default setup.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.title: Unclear what triggered a workflow run
/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.intro: If you don't know what triggered an analysis,  investigate the tool status page or look at the log for the last scan.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.title: Warning: "1 issue was detected with this workflow: git checkout HEAD^2 is no longer necessary"
/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.intro: If you see this warning, you should update your workflow to follow current best practice.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.title: Troubleshooting SARIF uploads
/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.intro: Learn how to resolve problems uploading SARIF files of code scanning results to GitHub.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.title: Upload fails because GitHub Advanced Security is disabled
/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.intro: You can only upload SARIF results to private or internal repositories where GitHub Advanced Security is enabled.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.title: Upload was rejected because CodeQL default setup is enabled for code scanning
/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.intro: You cannot upload SARIF results generated by the CodeQL action or CodeQL CLI when default setup for code scanning is enabled. Check your configuration and decide whether to keep default setup or unblock SARIF upload.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.title: GitHub token is required to upload SARIF results
/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.intro: You need to provide an authentication method for the upload process to use to access the repository.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.title: SARIF file is invalid
/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.intro: Code scanning can only process syntactically invalid SARIF files. Invalid files are rejected.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.title: SARIF results file is too large
/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.intro: You cannot upload a SARIF results file larger than 10 MB to code scanning. Explore ways to generate a smaller file containing the highest impact results.

/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.title: SARIF results exceed one or more limits
/en/code-security/code-scanning/troubles.intro: Learn how to resolve problems when a SARIF file is rejected by code scanning because one or more limits is exceeded.

/en/code-security/codeql-cli.title: Use the CodeQL CLI to secure your code
/en/code-security/codeql-cli.intro: Use CodeQL CLI to run CodeQL analyses locally.

/en/code-security/codeql-cli/getting-sta.title: Getting started with the CodeQL CLI
/en/code-security/codeql-cli/getting-sta.intro: You can use the CodeQL CLI to locally develop, test and run CodeQL queries on software projects.

/en/code-security/codeql-cli/getting-sta.title: About the CodeQL CLI
/en/code-security/codeql-cli/getting-sta.intro: You can use the CodeQL CLI to run CodeQL processes locally on software projects or to generate code scanning results for upload to GitHub.

/en/code-security/codeql-cli/getting-sta.title: Setting up the CodeQL CLI
/en/code-security/codeql-cli/getting-sta.intro: To get started with the CodeQL CLI, you need to download and set up the CLI so that it can access the tools and libraries required to create and analyze databases.

/en/code-security/codeql-cli/getting-sta.title: Preparing your code for CodeQL analysis
/en/code-security/codeql-cli/getting-sta.intro: You can build a CodeQL database containing the data needed to analyze your code.

/en/code-security/codeql-cli/getting-sta.title: Analyzing your code with CodeQL queries
/en/code-security/codeql-cli/getting-sta.intro: You can run queries against a CodeQL database extracted from a codebase.

/en/code-security/codeql-cli/getting-sta.title: Uploading CodeQL analysis results to GitHub
/en/code-security/codeql-cli/getting-sta.intro: You can use the CodeQL CLI to upload CodeQL analysis results to GitHub.

/en/code-security/codeql-cli/getting-sta.title: Customizing analysis with CodeQL packs
/en/code-security/codeql-cli/getting-sta.intro: You can use CodeQL packs to run CodeQL queries maintained by other people, or to share CodeQL queries that you've developed.

/en/code-security/codeql-cli/using-the-a.title: Using the advanced functionality of the CodeQL CLI
/en/code-security/codeql-cli/using-the-a.intro: You can use the CodeQL CLI to locally develop, test and run CodeQL queries on software projects.

/en/code-security/codeql-cli/using-the-a.title: Advanced setup of the CodeQL CLI
/en/code-security/codeql-cli/using-the-a.intro: You can modify your CodeQL CLI setup to use a local checkout of the CodeQL repository for analysis, set up multiple versions of the CodeQL CLI, and analyze databases you have downloaded from GitHub.com.

/en/code-security/codeql-cli/using-the-a.title: About CodeQL workspaces
/en/code-security/codeql-cli/using-the-a.intro: CodeQL workspaces allow you to develop and maintain a group of CodeQL packs that depend on each other.

/en/code-security/codeql-cli/using-the-a.title: Using custom queries with the CodeQL CLI
/en/code-security/codeql-cli/using-the-a.intro: You can write your own CodeQL queries to find specific vulnerabilities and errors.

/en/code-security/codeql-cli/using-the-a.title: Creating CodeQL query suites
/en/code-security/codeql-cli/using-the-a.intro: You can create query suites for queries you frequently use in your CodeQL analyses.

/en/code-security/codeql-cli/using-the-a.title: Testing custom queries
/en/code-security/codeql-cli/using-the-a.intro: You can set up tests for your CodeQL queries to ensure that they continue to return the expected results with new releases of the CodeQL CLI.

/en/code-security/codeql-cli/using-the-a.title: Testing query help files
/en/code-security/codeql-cli/using-the-a.intro: You can use the CodeQL CLI to preview your query help files as Markdown and ensure they are valid.

/en/code-security/codeql-cli/using-the-a.title: Creating and working with CodeQL packs
/en/code-security/codeql-cli/using-the-a.intro: You can use CodeQL packs to create, share, depend on, and run CodeQL queries and libraries.

/en/code-security/codeql-cli/using-the-a.title: Publishing and using CodeQL packs
/en/code-security/codeql-cli/using-the-a.intro: You can publish your own CodeQL packs and use packs published by other people.

/en/code-security/codeql-cli/using-the-a.title: Specifying command options in a CodeQL configuration file
/en/code-security/codeql-cli/using-the-a.intro: You can save default command options in a CodeQL configuration file.

/en/code-security/codeql-cli/using-the-a.title: Query reference files
/en/code-security/codeql-cli/using-the-a.intro: You can use query reference files to define the location of a query you want to run in tests.

/en/code-security/codeql-cli/using-the-a.title: CodeQL CLI SARIF output
/en/code-security/codeql-cli/using-the-a.intro: You can output SARIF from the CodeQL CLI and share static analysis results with other systems.

/en/code-security/codeql-cli/using-the-a.title: CodeQL CLI CSV output
/en/code-security/codeql-cli/using-the-a.intro: You can output results from the CodeQL CLI in CSV format to share with other systems.

/en/code-security/codeql-cli/using-the-a.title: Extractor options
/en/code-security/codeql-cli/using-the-a.intro: You can use the CodeQL CLI to run CodeQL processes locally on software projects.

/en/code-security/codeql-cli/using-the-a.title: Exit codes
/en/code-security/codeql-cli/using-the-a.intro: Exit codes signify the status of a command after the CodeQL CLI runs it.

/en/code-security/codeql-cli/codeql-cli-.title: CodeQL CLI commands manual
/en/code-security/codeql-cli/codeql-cli-.intro: Reference information for the commands available in the most recent release of CodeQL CLI.

/en/code-security/codeql-cli/codeql-cli-.title: bqrs decode
/en/code-security/codeql-cli/codeql-cli-.intro: Convert result data from BQRS into other forms.

/en/code-security/codeql-cli/codeql-cli-.title: bqrs diff
/en/code-security/codeql-cli/codeql-cli-.intro: Compute the difference between two result sets.

/en/code-security/codeql-cli/codeql-cli-.title: bqrs hash
/en/code-security/codeql-cli/codeql-cli-.intro: [Plumbing] Compute a stable hash of a BQRS file.

/en/code-security/codeql-cli/codeql-cli-.title: bqrs info
/en/code-security/codeql-cli/codeql-cli-.intro: Display metadata for a BQRS file.

/en/code-security/codeql-cli/codeql-cli-.title: bqrs interpret
/en/code-security/codeql-cli/codeql-cli-.intro: [Plumbing] Interpret data in a single BQRS.

/en/code-security/codeql-cli/codeql-cli-.title: database add-diagnostic
/en/code-security/codeql-cli/codeql-cli-.intro: [Experimental] Add a piece of diagnostic information to a database.

/en/code-security/codeql-cli/codeql-cli-.title: database analyze
/en/code-security/codeql-cli/codeql-cli-.intro:
Analyze a database, producing meaningful results in the context of the
source code.

/en/code-security/codeql-cli/codeql-cli-.title: database bundle
/en/code-security/codeql-cli/codeql-cli-.intro: Create a relocatable archive of a CodeQL database.

/en/code-security/codeql-cli/codeql-cli-.title: database cleanup
/en/code-security/codeql-cli/codeql-cli-.intro: Compact a CodeQL database on disk.

/en/code-security/codeql-cli/codeql-cli-.title: database create
/en/code-security/codeql-cli/codeql-cli-.intro:
Create a CodeQL database for a source tree that can be analyzed using
one of the CodeQL products.
