/en/code-security/security-advisories.title: Working with security advisories
/en/code-security/security-advisories.intro: Learn how to work with security advisories on GitHub, whether you want to contribute to an existing global advisory, or create a security advisory for a repository, improving collaboration between repository maintainers and security researchers.

/en/code-security/security-advisories/wo.title: Working with global security advisories from the GitHub Advisory Database
/en/code-security/security-advisories/wo.intro: Browse the GitHub Advisory Database and submit improvements to any global security advisory.

/en/code-security/security-advisories/wo.title: About the GitHub Advisory database
/en/code-security/security-advisories/wo.intro: The GitHub Advisory Database contains a list of known security vulnerabilities and malware, grouped in three categories: GitHub-reviewed advisories, unreviewed advisories, and malware advisories.

/en/code-security/security-advisories/wo.title: About global security advisories
/en/code-security/security-advisories/wo.intro: Global security advisories live in the GitHub Advisory Database, a collection of CVEs and GitHub-originated advisories affecting the open source world. You can contribute to improving global security advisories.

/en/code-security/security-advisories/wo.title: Browsing security advisories in the GitHub Advisory Database
/en/code-security/security-advisories/wo.intro: You can browse the GitHub Advisory Database to find CVEs and GitHub-originated advisories affecting the open source world.

/en/code-security/security-advisories/wo.title: Editing security advisories in the GitHub Advisory Database
/en/code-security/security-advisories/wo.intro: You can submit improvements to any advisory published in the GitHub Advisory Database.

/en/code-security/security-advisories/wo.title: Working with repository security advisories
/en/code-security/security-advisories/wo.intro: Discuss, fix, and disclose security vulnerabilities in your repositories using repository security advisories.

/en/code-security/security-advisories/wo.title: About repository security advisories
/en/code-security/security-advisories/wo.intro: You can use repository security advisories to privately discuss, fix, and publish information about security vulnerabilities in your repository.

/en/code-security/security-advisories/wo.title: Permission levels for repository security advisories
/en/code-security/security-advisories/wo.intro: The actions you can take in a repository security advisory depend on whether you have admin or write permissions to the security advisory.

/en/code-security/security-advisories/wo.title: Configuring private vulnerability reporting for a repository
/en/code-security/security-advisories/wo.intro: Owners and administrators of public repositories can allow security researchers to report vulnerabilities securely in the repository by enabling private vulnerability reporting.

/en/code-security/security-advisories/wo.title: Configuring private vulnerability reporting for an organization
/en/code-security/security-advisories/wo.intro: Organization owners and security managers can allow security researchers to report vulnerabilities securely in repositories within the organization by enabling private vulnerability reporting for all its public repositories.

/en/code-security/security-advisories/wo.title: Creating a repository security advisory
/en/code-security/security-advisories/wo.intro: You can create a draft security advisory to privately discuss and fix a security vulnerability in your open source project.

/en/code-security/security-advisories/wo.title: Editing a repository security advisory
/en/code-security/security-advisories/wo.intro: You can edit the metadata and description for a repository security advisory if you need to update details or correct errors.

/en/code-security/security-advisories/wo.title: Evaluating the security settings of a repository
/en/code-security/security-advisories/wo.intro: Security researchers can assess the security settings of a public repository, suggest a security policy and report a vulnerability.

/en/code-security/security-advisories/wo.title: Collaborating in a temporary private fork to resolve a repository security vulnerability
/en/code-security/security-advisories/wo.intro: You can create a temporary private fork to privately collaborate on fixing a security vulnerability in your repository.

/en/code-security/security-advisories/wo.title: Publishing a repository security advisory
/en/code-security/security-advisories/wo.intro: You can publish a security advisory to alert your community about a security vulnerability in your project.

/en/code-security/security-advisories/wo.title: Adding a collaborator to a repository security advisory
/en/code-security/security-advisories/wo.intro: You can add other users or teams to collaborate on a security advisory with you.

/en/code-security/security-advisories/wo.title: Removing a collaborator from a repository security advisory
/en/code-security/security-advisories/wo.intro: When you remove a collaborator from a repository security advisory, they lose read and write access to the security advisory's discussion and metadata.

/en/code-security/security-advisories/wo.title: Withdrawing a repository security advisory
/en/code-security/security-advisories/wo.intro: You can withdraw a repository security advisory that you've published.

/en/code-security/security-advisories/gu.title: Guidance on reporting and writing information about vulnerabilities
/en/code-security/security-advisories/gu.intro: Best practices for writing security advisories and managing privately reported security vulnerabilities.

/en/code-security/security-advisories/gu.title: About coordinated disclosure of security vulnerabilities
/en/code-security/security-advisories/gu.intro: Vulnerability disclosure is a coordinated effort between security reporters and repository maintainers.

/en/code-security/security-advisories/gu.title: Best practices for writing repository security advisories
/en/code-security/security-advisories/gu.intro: When you create or edit security advisories, the information you provide is easier for other users to understand when you specify the ecosystem, package name, and affected versions using the standard formats.

/en/code-security/security-advisories/gu.title: Privately reporting a security vulnerability
/en/code-security/security-advisories/gu.intro: Some public repositories configure security advisories so that anyone can report security vulnerabilities directly and privately to the maintainers.

/en/code-security/security-advisories/gu.title: Managing privately reported security vulnerabilities
/en/code-security/security-advisories/gu.intro: Repository maintainers can manage security vulnerabilities that have been privately reported to them by security researchers for repositories where private vulnerability reporting is enabled.

/en/code-security/supply-chain-security.title: Securing your software supply chain
/en/code-security/supply-chain-security.intro: Visualize, maintain, and secure the dependencies in your software supply chain.

/en/code-security/supply-chain-security/.title: About supply chain security
/en/code-security/supply-chain-security/.intro: GitHub helps you secure your supply chain, from understanding the dependencies in your environment, to knowing about vulnerabilities in those dependencies, and patching them.

/en/code-security/supply-chain-security/.title: About the dependency graph
/en/code-security/supply-chain-security/.intro: You can use the dependency graph to identify all your project's dependencies. The dependency graph supports a range of popular package ecosystems.

/en/code-security/supply-chain-security/.title: Configuring the dependency graph
/en/code-security/supply-chain-security/.intro: You can allow users to identify their projects' dependencies by enabling the dependency graph.

/en/code-security/supply-chain-security/.title: Exporting a software bill of materials for your repository
/en/code-security/supply-chain-security/.intro: You can export a software bill of materials or SBOM for your repository from the dependency graph. SBOMs allow transparency into your open source usage and help expose supply chain vulnerabilities, reducing supply chain risks.

/en/code-security/supply-chain-security/.title: Using the Dependency submission API
/en/code-security/supply-chain-security/.intro: You can use the Dependency submission API to submit dependencies for projects, such as the dependencies resolved when a project is built or compiled.

/en/code-security/supply-chain-security/.title: About dependency review
/en/code-security/supply-chain-security/.intro: Dependency review lets you catch insecure dependencies before you introduce them to your environment, and provides information on license, dependents, and age of dependencies.

/en/code-security/supply-chain-security/.title: Configuring dependency review
/en/code-security/supply-chain-security/.intro: You can use dependency review to catch vulnerabilities before they are added to your project.

/en/code-security/supply-chain-security/.title: Exploring the dependencies of a repository
/en/code-security/supply-chain-security/.intro: You can use the dependency graph to see the packages your project depends on and the repositories that depend on it. In addition, you can see any vulnerabilities detected in its dependencies.

/en/code-security/supply-chain-security/.title: Troubleshooting the dependency graph
/en/code-security/supply-chain-security/.intro: If the dependency information reported by the dependency graph is not what you expected, there are a number of points to consider, and various things you can check.

/en/code-security/supply-chain-security/.title: End-to-end supply chain
/en/code-security/supply-chain-security/.intro: How to think about securing your user accounts, your code, and your build process

/en/code-security/supply-chain-security/.title: Securing your end-to-end supply chain
/en/code-security/supply-chain-security/.intro: Introducing best practice guides on complete end-to-end supply chain security including personal accounts, code, and build processes.

/en/code-security/supply-chain-security/.title: Best practices for securing accounts
/en/code-security/supply-chain-security/.intro: Guidance on how to protect accounts with access to your software supply chain.

/en/code-security/supply-chain-security/.title: Best practices for securing code in your supply chain
/en/code-security/supply-chain-security/.intro: Guidance on how to protect the center of your supply chain—the code you write and the code you depend on.

/en/code-security/supply-chain-security/.title: Best practices for securing your build system
/en/code-security/supply-chain-security/.intro: Guidance on how to protect the end of your supply chain—the systems you use to build and distribute artifacts.

/en/code-security/dependabot.title: Keeping your supply chain secure with Dependabot
/en/code-security/dependabot.intro: Monitor vulnerabilities in dependencies used in your project and keep your dependencies up-to-date with Dependabot.

/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-.title: Identifying vulnerabilities in your project's dependencies with Dependabot alerts
/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-.intro: Dependabot generates Dependabot alerts when known vulnerabilities are detected in dependencies that your project uses.

/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-.title: About Dependabot alerts
/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-.intro: GitHub sends Dependabot alerts when we detect that your repository uses a vulnerable dependency.

/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-.title: Configuring Dependabot alerts
/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-.intro: Enable Dependabot alerts to be generated when a new vulnerable dependency is found in one of your repositories.

/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-.title: Viewing and updating Dependabot alerts
/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-.intro: If GitHub discovers insecure dependencies in your project, you can view details on the Dependabot alerts tab of your repository. Then, you can update your project to resolve or dismiss the alert.

/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-.title: Configuring notifications for Dependabot alerts
/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-.intro: Optimize how you receive notifications about  Dependabot alerts.

/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-.title: Prioritizing Dependabot alerts with Dependabot auto-triage rules
/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-.intro: You can use Dependabot auto-triage rules to prioritize Dependabot alerts.

/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-.title: About Dependabot auto-triage rules
/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-.intro: Dependabot auto-triage rules are a powerful tool to help you better manage your security alerts at scale. Dependabot's default rules are curated for you and filter out a substantial amount of false positives. Custom auto-triage rules provide control over which alerts are ignored, snoozed, or trigger a Dependabot security update to resolve the alert.

/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-.title: Using GitHub-curated default rules to prioritize Dependabot alerts
/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-.intro: You can use a GitHub-curated default rule to auto-dismiss low impact development alerts for npm dependencies.

/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-.title: Customizing auto-triage rules to prioritize Dependabot alerts
/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-.intro: You can create your own auto-triage rules to control which alerts are dismissed or snoozed, and which alerts you want Dependabot to open pull requests for.

/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-.title: Managing alerts that have been automatically dismissed by a Dependabot auto-triage rule
/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-.intro: You can filter to see which alerts have been auto-dismissed by a rule, and you can reopen dismissed alerts.

/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-.title: Automatically updating dependencies with known vulnerabilities with Dependabot security updates
/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-.intro: Dependabot can help you fix vulnerable dependencies by automatically raising pull requests to update dependencies to secure versions.

/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-.title: About Dependabot security updates
/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-.intro: Dependabot can fix vulnerable dependencies for you by raising pull requests with security updates.

/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-.title: Configuring Dependabot security updates
/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-.intro: You can use Dependabot security updates or manual pull requests to easily update vulnerable dependencies.

/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-.title: Keeping your dependencies updated automatically with Dependabot version updates
/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-.intro: You can use Dependabot to automatically keep the dependencies and packages used in your repository updated to the latest version, even when they don’t have any known vulnerabilities.

/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-.title: About Dependabot version updates
/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-.intro: You can use Dependabot to keep the packages you use updated to the latest versions.

/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-.title: Configuring Dependabot version updates
/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-.intro: You can configure your repository so that Dependabot automatically updates the packages you use.

/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-.title: Listing dependencies configured for version updates
/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-.intro: You can view the dependencies that Dependabot monitors for updates.

/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-.title: Customizing dependency updates
/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-.intro: You can customize how Dependabot maintains your dependencies.

/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-.title: Configuration options for the dependabot.yml file
/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-.intro: Detailed information for all the options you can use to customize how Dependabot maintains your repositories.

/en/code-security/dependabot/working-wit.title: Working with Dependabot
/en/code-security/dependabot/working-wit.intro: Guidance and recommendations for working with Dependabot, such as managing pull requests raised by Dependabot, using GitHub Actions with Dependabot, and troubleshooting Dependabot errors.

/en/code-security/dependabot/working-wit.title: Managing pull requests for dependency updates
/en/code-security/dependabot/working-wit.intro: You manage pull requests raised by Dependabot in much the same way as other pull requests, but there are some extra options.

/en/code-security/dependabot/working-wit.title: Automating Dependabot with GitHub Actions
/en/code-security/dependabot/working-wit.intro: Examples of how you can use GitHub Actions to automate common Dependabot related tasks.

/en/code-security/dependabot/working-wit.title: Keeping your actions up to date with Dependabot
/en/code-security/dependabot/working-wit.intro: You can use Dependabot to keep the actions you use updated to the latest versions.

/en/code-security/dependabot/working-wit.title: Configuring access to private registries for Dependabot
/en/code-security/dependabot/working-wit.intro: You can configure Dependabot to access dependencies stored in private registries. You can store authentication information, like passwords and access tokens, as encrypted secrets and then reference these in the Dependabot configuration file. You can also add Dependabot to your registries IP allow list.

/en/code-security/dependabot/working-wit.title: Guidance for the configuration of private registries for Dependabot
/en/code-security/dependabot/working-wit.intro: This article contains detailed information about configuring private registries, as well as commands you can run from the command line to configure your package managers locally.

/en/code-security/dependabot/working-wit.title: Removing Dependabot access to public registries
/en/code-security/dependabot/working-wit.intro: Examples of how you can configure Dependabot to only access private registries by removing calls to public registries.

/en/code-security/dependabot/working-wit.title: Viewing Dependabot job logs
/en/code-security/dependabot/working-wit.intro: To support debugging of Dependabot pull requests, GitHub provides logs of all Dependabot jobs.

/en/code-security/dependabot/working-wit.title: Troubleshooting the detection of vulnerable dependencies
/en/code-security/dependabot/working-wit.intro: If the dependency information reported by GitHub is not what you expected, there are a number of points to consider, and various things you can check.

/en/code-security/dependabot/working-wit.title: Troubleshooting Dependabot errors
/en/code-security/dependabot/working-wit.intro: Sometimes Dependabot is unable to raise a pull request to update your dependencies. You can review the error and unblock Dependabot.

/en/code-security/security-overview.title: Viewing security information for your organization or enterprise
/en/code-security/security-overview.intro: View, sort, and filter security alerts and coverage information from across your organization or enterprise, and enable security features for their repositories.

/en/code-security/security-overview/abou.title: About security overview
/en/code-security/security-overview/abou.intro: You can gain insights into the overall security landscape of your organization and view summaries of alerts for repositories owned by your organization.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/code-securit.title: Viewing security insights for your organization
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/code-securit.intro: You can use the overview dashboard in security overview to monitor the security landscape of the repositories in your organization.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/code-securit.title: Assessing adoption of code security features
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/code-securit.intro: You can use security overview to see which teams and repositories have already enabled code security features, and identify any that are not yet protected.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/code-securit.title: Assessing your code security risk
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/code-securit.intro: You can use security overview to see which teams and repositories are affected by security alerts, and identify repositories for urgent remedial action.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/code-securit.title: Filtering alerts in security overview
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/code-securit.intro: Use filters to view specific categories of alerts

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/code-securit.title: Enabling security features for multiple repositories
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/code-securit.intro: You can use security overview to select a subset of repositories and enable security features for them all.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/code-securit.title: Exporting data from the risk and coverage pages
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/code-securit.intro: You can export CSV files of your risk and coverage data from security overview.

/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/code-securit.title: Viewing metrics for secret scanning push protection in your organization
/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/code-securit.intro: You can use security overview to see how secret scanning push protection is performing in repositories across your organization, and to identify repositories where you may need to take action.

/en/pull-requests.title: Pull requests documentation
/en/pull-requests.intro: Learn how to use pull requests to suggest changes to a project, receive suggested changes to your own projects, and address issues in pull requests, such as merge conflicts.

/en/pull-requests/committing-changes-to-.title: Committing changes to your project
/en/pull-requests/committing-changes-to-.intro: You can manage code changes in a repository by grouping work into commits.

/en/pull-requests/committing-changes-to-.title: About commits
/en/pull-requests/committing-changes-to-.intro: You can save small groups of meaningful changes as commits.

/en/pull-requests/committing-changes-to-.title: Creating a commit with multiple authors
/en/pull-requests/committing-changes-to-.intro: You can attribute a commit to more than one author by adding one or more Co-authored-by trailers to the commit's message. Co-authored commits are visible on GitHub.

/en/pull-requests/committing-changes-to-.title: Creating a commit on behalf of an organization
/en/pull-requests/committing-changes-to-.intro: You can create commits on behalf of an organization by adding a  trailer to the commit's message. Commits attributed to an organization include an on-behalf-of badge on GitHub.

/en/pull-requests/committing-changes-to-.title: Changing a commit message
/en/pull-requests/committing-changes-to-.intro: If a commit message contains unclear, incorrect, or sensitive information, you can amend it locally and push a new commit with a new message to GitHub. You can also change a commit message to add missing information.

/en/pull-requests/committing-changes-to-.title: Comparing commits
/en/pull-requests/committing-changes-to-.intro: You can compare the state of your repository across branches, tags, commits, forks, and dates.

/en/pull-requests/committing-changes-to-.title: Differences between commit views
/en/pull-requests/committing-changes-to-.intro: You might observe differences in commit history depending on the chosen viewing method.

/en/pull-requests/committing-changes-to-.title: Commit exists on GitHub but not in my local clone
/en/pull-requests/committing-changes-to-.intro: Sometimes a commit will be viewable on GitHub, but will not exist in your local clone of the repository.

/en/pull-requests/committing-changes-to-.title: Why are my commits linked to the wrong user?
/en/pull-requests/committing-changes-to-.intro: GitHub uses the email address in the commit header to link the commit to a GitHub user. If your commits are being linked to another user, or not linked to a user at all, you may need to change your local Git configuration settings, add an email address to your account email settings, or do both.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: Collaborating with pull requests
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: Track and discuss changes in issues, then propose and review changes in pull requests.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: Getting started
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: Learn about the GitHub flow and different ways to collaborate on and discuss your projects.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: About collaborative development models
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: The way you use pull requests depends on the type of development model you use in your project. You can use the fork and pull model or the shared repository model.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: Best practices for pull requests
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: You can follow best practices to improve the consistency and quality of pull requests and pull request reviews.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: Working with forks
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: Forks are often used in open source development on GitHub.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: About forks
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: A fork is a new repository that shares code and visibility settings with the original “upstream” repository.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: Fork a repository
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: A fork is a new repository that shares code and visibility settings with the original “upstream” repository.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: About permissions and visibility of forks
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: The permissions and visibility of forks depend on whether the upstream repository is public or private, and whether it is owned by an organization.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: Configuring a remote repository for a fork
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: You must configure a remote that points to the upstream repository in Git to sync changes you make in a fork with the original repository. This also allows you to sync changes made in the original repository with the fork.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: Syncing a fork
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: Sync a fork of a repository to keep it up-to-date with the upstream repository.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: Allowing changes to a pull request branch created from a fork
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: For greater collaboration, you can allow commits on branches you've created from forks owned by your personal account.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: What happens to forks when a repository is deleted or changes visibility?
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: Deleting your repository or changing its visibility affects that repository's forks.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: Detaching a fork
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: You can delete a fork and recreate the same repository, without the connection to the original network.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: Collaborating on repositories with code quality features
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: Workflow quality features like statuses, protected branches, and required status checks help collaborators make contributions that meet conditions set by organization and repository administrators.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: About status checks
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: Status checks let you know if your commits meet the conditions set for the repository you're contributing to.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: Troubleshooting required status checks
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: You can check for common errors and resolve issues with required status checks.

/en/enterprise-server@3.11/pull-requests.title: Working with pre-receive hooks
/en/enterprise-server@3.11/pull-requests.intro: Pre-receive hooks enforce rules for contributions before commits may be pushed to a repository.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: Proposing changes to your work with pull requests
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: After you add changes to a topic branch or fork, you can open a pull request to ask your collaborators or the repository administrator to review your changes before merging them into the project.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: About branches
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: Use a branch to isolate development work without affecting other branches in the repository. Each repository has one default branch, and can have multiple other branches. You can merge a branch into another branch using a pull request.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: Creating and deleting branches within your repository
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: You can create or delete branches directly on GitHub.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: About pull requests
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: Pull requests let you tell others about changes you've pushed to a branch in a repository on GitHub. Once a pull request is opened, you can discuss and review the potential changes with collaborators and add follow-up commits before your changes are merged into the base branch.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: About comparing branches in pull requests
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: Pull requests display diffs to compare the changes you made in your topic branch against the base branch that you want to merge your changes into.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: Creating a pull request
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: Create a pull request to propose and collaborate on changes to a repository. These changes are proposed in a branch, which ensures that the default branch only contains finished and approved work.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: Creating a pull request from a fork
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: You can create a pull request to propose changes you've made to a fork of an upstream repository.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: Using query parameters to create a pull request
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: Use query parameters to create custom URLs to open pull requests with pre-populated fields.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: Changing the stage of a pull request
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: You can mark a draft pull request as ready for review or convert a pull request to a draft.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: Requesting a pull request review
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: After you create a pull request, you can ask a specific person to review the changes you've proposed. If you're an organization member, you can also request a specific team to review your changes.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: Keeping your pull request in sync with the base branch
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: After you open a pull request, you can update the head branch, which contains your changes, with any changes that have been made in the base branch.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: Changing the base branch of a pull request
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: After a pull request is opened, you can change the base branch to compare the changes in the pull request against a different branch.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: Committing changes to a pull request branch created from a fork
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: You can commit changes on a pull request branch that was created from a fork of your repository with permission from the pull request creator.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: Addressing merge conflicts
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: If your changes have merge conflicts with the base branch, you must address the merge conflicts before you can merge your pull request's changes.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: About merge conflicts
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: Merge conflicts happen when you merge branches that have competing commits, and Git needs your help to decide which changes to incorporate in the final merge.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: Resolving a merge conflict on GitHub
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: You can resolve simple merge conflicts that involve competing line changes on GitHub, using the conflict editor.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: Resolving a merge conflict using the command line
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: You can resolve merge conflicts using the command line and a text editor.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: Reviewing changes in pull requests
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: After a pull request has been opened, you can review and discuss the set of proposed changes.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: About pull request reviews
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: Reviews allow collaborators to comment on the changes proposed in pull requests, approve the changes, or request further changes before the pull request is merged. Repository administrators can require that all pull requests are approved before being merged.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: Reviewing proposed changes in a pull request
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: In a pull request, you can review and discuss commits, changed files, and the differences (or "diff") between the files in the base and compare branches.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: Filtering files in a pull request
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: To help you quickly review changes in a large pull request, you can filter changed files or use the file tree to navigate between files.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: Finding changed methods and functions in a pull request
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: You can quickly find proposed changes to a method or function in a pull request in .go, .js, .ts, .py, .php, and .rb files.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: Commenting on a pull request
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: After you open a pull request in a repository, collaborators or team members can comment on the comparison of files between the two specified branches, or leave general comments on the project as a whole.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: Viewing a pull request review
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: You can view all of the comments made in a single pull request review.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: Reviewing dependency changes in a pull request
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: If a pull request contains changes to dependencies, you can view a summary of what has changed and whether there are known vulnerabilities in any of the dependencies.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: Incorporating feedback in your pull request
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: When reviewers suggest changes in a pull request, you can automatically incorporate the changes into the pull request or open an issue to track out-of-scope suggestions.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: Approving a pull request with required reviews
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: If your repository requires reviews, pull requests must have a specific number of approving reviews from people with write or admin permissions in the repository before they can be merged.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: Dismissing a pull request review
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: If your repository requires reviews, you can dismiss pull request reviews that are no longer valid or are unable to be approved by the reviewer.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: Checking out pull requests locally
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: When someone sends you a pull request from a fork or branch of your repository, you can merge it locally to resolve a merge conflict or to test and verify the changes before merging on GitHub.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: Incorporating changes from a pull request
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: You can propose changes to your work on GitHub through pull requests. Learn how to create, manage, and merge pull requests.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: About pull request merges
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: You can merge pull requests by retaining all the commits in a feature branch, squashing all commits into a single commit, or by rebasing individual commits from the head branch onto the base branch.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: Merging a pull request
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: Merge a pull request into the upstream branch when work is completed. Anyone with push access to the repository can complete the merge.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: Automatically merging a pull request
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: You can increase development velocity by enabling auto-merge for a pull request so that the pull request will merge automatically when all merge requirements are met.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: Merging a pull request with a merge queue
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: If a merge queue is required by the branch protection setting for the branch, you can add your pull requests to a merge queue and GitHub will merge the pull requests for you once all required checks have passed.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: Closing a pull request
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: You may choose to close a pull request without merging it into the upstream branch. This can be handy if the changes proposed in the branch are no longer needed, or if another solution has been proposed in another branch.

/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.title: Reverting a pull request
/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pul.intro: You can revert a pull request after it's been merged to the upstream branch.

/en/issues.title: GitHub Issues documentation
/en/issues.intro: Learn how you can use GitHub Issues to plan and track your work.

/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issue.title: Tracking your work with issues
/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issue.intro: Use GitHub Issues to track ideas and work on GitHub

/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issue.title: About issues
/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issue.intro: Use GitHub Issues to track ideas, feedback, tasks, or bugs for work on GitHub.

/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issue.title: Quickstart for GitHub Issues
/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issue.intro: Follow this brief interactive guide to learn about GitHub Issues.

/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issue.title: Creating an issue
/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issue.intro: Issues can be created in a variety of ways, so you can choose the most convenient method for your workflow.

/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issue.title: About slash commands
/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issue.intro: Slash commands can save you time by reducing the typing required to create complex Markdown.

/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issue.title: Linking a pull request to an issue
/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issue.intro: You can link a pull request or branch to an issue to show that a fix is in progress and to automatically close the issue when the pull request or branch  is merged.

/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issue.title: Creating a branch to work on an issue
/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issue.intro: You can create a branch to work on an issue directly from the issue page and get started right away.

/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issue.title: Assigning issues and pull requests to other GitHub users
/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issue.intro: Assignees clarify who is working on specific issues and pull requests.

/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issue.title: Viewing all of your issues and pull requests
/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issue.intro: The Issues and Pull Request dashboards list the open issues and pull requests you've created. You can use them to update items that have gone stale, close them, or keep track of where you've been mentioned across all repositories—including those you're not subscribed to.

/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issue.title: Filtering and searching issues and pull requests
/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issue.intro: To find detailed information about a repository on GitHub, you can filter, sort, and search issues and pull requests that are relevant to the repository.

/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issue.title: Marking issues or pull requests as a duplicate
/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issue.intro: Mark an issue or pull request as a duplicate to track similar issues or pull requests together and remove unnecessary burden for both maintainers and collaborators.

/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issue.title: Pinning an issue to your repository
/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issue.intro: You can pin up to three important issues above the issues list in your repository.

/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issue.title: Transferring an issue to another repository
/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issue.intro: To move an issue to a better fitting repository, you can transfer open issues to other repositories.

/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issue.title: Closing an issue
/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issue.intro: You can close an issue when bugs are fixed, feedback is acted on, or to show that work is not planned.

/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issue.title: Deleting an issue
/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issue.intro: People with admin permissions in a repository can permanently delete an issue from a repository.

/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issue.title: Planning and tracking work for your team or project
/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issue.intro: The essentials for using GitHub's planning and tracking tools to manage work on a team or project.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: Planning and tracking with Projects
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: Build adaptable projects to track your work on GitHub.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: Learning about Projects
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: Learn about Projects and how to make the very best of this powerful tool.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: About Projects
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: Projects is an adaptable, flexible tool for planning and tracking work on GitHub.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: Quickstart for Projects
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: Experience the speed, flexibility, and customization of Projects by creating a project in this interactive guide.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: Best practices for Projects
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: Learn tips for managing your projects.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: Finding your projects
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: Learn how to locate projects in your account, organizations, repositories, and teams.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: Creating projects
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: Learn about creating projects and migrating your classic projects.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: Creating a project
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: Learn how to create an organization or user project.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: Copying an existing project
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: You can use an existing project as a template by copying it.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: Migrating from projects (classic)
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: You can migrate your classic project to the new Projects experience.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: Managing items in your project
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: Learn how to add and manage issues, pull requests, and draft issues.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: Adding items to your project
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: Learn how to add pull requests, issues, and draft issues to your projects individually or in bulk.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: Converting draft issues to issues
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: Learn how to convert draft issues into issues.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: Editing items in your project
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: There are several methods you can use within your project to quickly make changes to multiple items.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: Archiving items from your project
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: You can archive items, keeping them available to restore, or permanently delete them.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: Understanding fields
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: Learn about the different fields and custom field types, how to add fields to your project, and how to manage custom fields.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: About text and number fields
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: You can add custom text and number fields to your project.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: About date fields
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: You can create custom date fields that can be set by typing a date or using a calendar.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: About single select fields
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: You can create single select fields with multiple options, each with a description and a color, that can be selected from a dropdown menu.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: About iteration fields
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: You can create iterations to plan upcoming work and group items.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: About Tracks and Tracked by fields
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: You can view the subtasks of the issues in your projects.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: Renaming custom fields
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: Learn about renaming existing custom fields in your project.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: Deleting custom fields
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: Learn how to delete a custom field from your project.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: Customizing views in your project
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: You can create multiple views to look at your project from different angles, deciding which items to show and how to present them.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: Changing the layout of a view
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: You can view your project as a high-density table, as a kanban board, or as a timeline-style roadmap.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: Customizing the table layout
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: You can use the table layout to build a spreadsheet using your project's items,  GitHub metadata, and your custom fields.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: Customizing the board layout
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: You can use the board layout to arrange your project's items over customizable columns.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: Customizing the roadmap layout
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: You can use the roadmap layout to view your project's items on a timeline.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: Filtering projects
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: Use filters to choose which items appear in your project's views.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: Managing your views
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: Learn how to create, save, and manage your project views.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: Automating your project
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: Learn how to use the built-in workflows, GitHub Actions, and the API to automate your projects.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: Using the built-in automations
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: You can use built-in workflows to automate your projects.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: Using the API to manage Projects
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: You can use the GraphQL API to automate your projects.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: Automating Projects using Actions
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: You can use GitHub Actions to automate your projects.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: Adding items automatically
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: You can configure your project's built-in workflows to automatically add items from repositories that match a filter.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: Archiving items automatically
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: You can configure your project's built-in workflows to automatically archive items that match a filter.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: Viewing insights from your project
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: You can use insights to visualize your projects by creating and sharing charts built from your project's data.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: About insights for Projects
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: You can view and customize charts that are built from your project's data.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: Creating charts
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: Learn how to create new charts to save your configurations.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: Configuring charts
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: Learn how to configure your charts and filter data from your project.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: Managing your project
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: Learn how to manage your projects and control visibility and access.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: Managing visibility of your projects
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: Learn about setting your project to private or public visibility.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: Managing access to your projects
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: Learn how to manage team and individual access to your project.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: Managing project templates in your organization
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: You can create templates or set projects as templates in your organization, allowing other people to select your template as the base for projects they create.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: Closing and deleting your projects
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: Learn about closing, re-opening, and permanently deleting a project.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: Adding your project to a repository
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: You can add your project to a repository to make it accessible from that repository.

/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.title: Adding your project to a team
/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-pr.intro: You can add projects to teams to manage permissions and improve project discoverability.

/en/issues/managing-your-tasks-with-task.title: Managing your issues with tasklists
/en/issues/managing-your-tasks-with-task.intro: You can use tasklists to divide your issues into smaller subtasks.

/en/issues/managing-your-tasks-with-task.title: About tasklists
/en/issues/managing-your-tasks-with-task.intro: You can use tasklists to quickly sketch out projects, divide tasks into subtasks, and track issues and pull requests.

/en/issues/managing-your-tasks-with-task.title: Quickstart for tasklists
/en/issues/managing-your-tasks-with-task.intro: Follow this guide to learn how to create and modify tasklists in the UI and with Markdown.

/en/issues/managing-your-tasks-with-task.title: Creating a tasklist
/en/issues/managing-your-tasks-with-task.intro: You can create a tasklist using the GitHub UI or Markdown.

/en/issues/managing-your-tasks-with-task.title: Managing tasks in a tasklist
/en/issues/managing-your-tasks-with-task.intro: You can track issues and pull requests as subtasks in a tasklist. You can also add draft tasks and later convert them into issues.

/en/issues/managing-your-tasks-with-task.title: Using projects and tasklists
/en/issues/managing-your-tasks-with-task.intro: When issues in your project are tracked by tasklists or contain tasklists, you can use them to create views and filters.

/en/issues/organizing-your-work-with-pro.title: Organizing your work with projects (classic)
/en/issues/organizing-your-work-with-pro.intro: Use projects (classic) to manage your work on GitHub

/en/issues/organizing-your-work-with-pro.title: Managing projects (classic)
/en/issues/organizing-your-work-with-pro.intro: Learn how to create and manage classic projects

/en/issues/organizing-your-work-with-pro.title: About projects (classic)
/en/issues/organizing-your-work-with-pro.intro: Projects (classic) on GitHub help you organize and prioritize your work. You can create classic projects for specific feature work, comprehensive roadmaps, or even release checklists. With projects (classic), you have the flexibility to create customized workflows that suit your needs.

/en/issues/organizing-your-work-with-pro.title: Creating a project (classic)
/en/issues/organizing-your-work-with-pro.intro: Classic projects can be used to create customized workflows to suit your needs, like tracking and prioritizing specific feature work, comprehensive roadmaps, or even release checklists.

/en/issues/organizing-your-work-with-pro.title: Editing a project (classic)
/en/issues/organizing-your-work-with-pro.intro: You can edit the title and description of an existing classic project.

/en/issues/organizing-your-work-with-pro.title: Linking a repository to a project (classic)
/en/issues/organizing-your-work-with-pro.intro: You can link a repository to your organization's or personal account's classic project.

/en/issues/organizing-your-work-with-pro.title: About automation for projects (classic)
/en/issues/organizing-your-work-with-pro.intro: You can configure automatic workflows to keep the status of classic project cards in sync with the associated issues and pull requests.

/en/issues/organizing-your-work-with-pro.title: Configuring automation for projects (classic)
/en/issues/organizing-your-work-with-pro.intro: You can set up automatic workflows to move issues and pull requests to a classic project column when a specified event occurs.

/en/issues/organizing-your-work-with-pro.title: Copying a project (classic)
/en/issues/organizing-your-work-with-pro.intro: You can copy a classic project to quickly create a new project. Copying frequently used or highly customized classic projects helps standardize your workflow.

/en/issues/organizing-your-work-with-pro.title: Changing project (classic) visibility
/en/issues/organizing-your-work-with-pro.intro: As an organization owner or classic project admin, you can make a classic project public or private.

/en/issues/organizing-your-work-with-pro.title: Closing a project (classic)
/en/issues/organizing-your-work-with-pro.intro: If you've completed all the tasks in a classic project or no longer need to use a classic project, you can close the classic project.

/en/issues/organizing-your-work-with-pro.title: Reopening a closed project (classic)
/en/issues/organizing-your-work-with-pro.intro: You can reopen a closed classic project and restart any workflow automation that was configured for the classic project.

/en/issues/organizing-your-work-with-pro.title: Deleting a project (classic)
/en/issues/organizing-your-work-with-pro.intro: You can delete an existing classic project if you no longer need access to its contents.

/en/issues/organizing-your-work-with-pro.title: Tracking progress on your projects (classic)
/en/issues/organizing-your-work-with-pro.intro: Learn how to track your work on classic project

/en/issues/organizing-your-work-with-pro.title: Adding issues and pull requests to a project (classic)
/en/issues/organizing-your-work-with-pro.intro: You can add issues and pull requests to a classic project in the form of cards and triage them into columns.

/en/issues/organizing-your-work-with-pro.title: Adding notes to a project (classic)
/en/issues/organizing-your-work-with-pro.intro: You can add notes to a classic project to serve as task reminders or to add information related to the classic project.

/en/issues/organizing-your-work-with-pro.title: Tracking progress on your project (classic)
/en/issues/organizing-your-work-with-pro.intro: You can see the overall progress of your classic project in a progress bar.

/en/issues/organizing-your-work-with-pro.title: Filtering cards on a project (classic)
/en/issues/organizing-your-work-with-pro.intro: You can filter the cards on a classic project to search for specific cards or view a subset of the cards.

/en/issues/organizing-your-work-with-pro.title: Archiving cards on a project (classic)
/en/issues/organizing-your-work-with-pro.intro: You can archive classic project cards to declutter your workflow without losing the historical context of a project.

/en/issues/using-labels-and-milestones-t.title: Using labels and milestones to track work
/en/issues/using-labels-and-milestones-t.intro: Use labels and milestones to categorize and track work on GitHub.

/en/issues/using-labels-and-milestones-t.title: Managing labels
/en/issues/using-labels-and-milestones-t.intro: You can classify issues, pull requests, and discussions by creating, editing, applying, and deleting labels.

/en/issues/using-labels-and-milestones-t.title: About milestones
/en/issues/using-labels-and-milestones-t.intro: You can use milestones to track progress on groups of issues or pull requests in a repository.

/en/issues/using-labels-and-milestones-t.title: Creating and editing milestones for issues and pull requests
/en/issues/using-labels-and-milestones-t.intro: You can create a milestone to track progress on groups of issues or pull requests in a repository.

/en/issues/using-labels-and-milestones-t.title: Associating milestones with issues and pull requests
/en/issues/using-labels-and-milestones-t.intro: You can associate similar issues and pull requests with a milestone to better track their progress.

/en/issues/using-labels-and-milestones-t.title: Filtering issues and pull requests by milestone
/en/issues/using-labels-and-milestones-t.intro: Issues and pull requests can be filtered based on the milestone they're associated with. Once you've associated an issue or pull request with a milestone, you can find items based on their milestones. Within a milestone, you can prioritize issues and pull requests.

/en/issues/using-labels-and-milestones-t.title: Viewing your milestone's progress
/en/issues/using-labels-and-milestones-t.intro: In order to track your milestones, you'll want to get a better understanding of how many open issues and pull requests are remaining.

/en/issues/guides.title: Guides for Issues
/en/issues/guides.intro: Learn how you can use GitHub Issues to plan and track your work.

/en/actions.title: GitHub Actions documentation
/en/actions.intro: Automate, customize, and execute your software development workflows right in your repository with GitHub Actions. You can discover, create, and share actions to perform any job you'd like, including CI/CD, and combine actions in a completely customized workflow.

/en/actions/quickstart.title: Quickstart for GitHub Actions
/en/actions/quickstart.intro: Try out the features of GitHub Actions in 5 minutes or less.

/en/actions/learn-github-actions.title: Learn GitHub Actions
/en/actions/learn-github-actions.intro: Whether you are new to GitHub Actions or interested in learning all they have to offer, this guide will help you use GitHub Actions to accelerate your application development workflows.

/en/actions/learn-github-actions/underst.title: Understanding GitHub Actions
/en/actions/learn-github-actions/underst.intro: Learn the basics of GitHub Actions, including core concepts and essential terminology.

/en/actions/learn-github-actions/finding.title: Finding and customizing actions
/en/actions/learn-github-actions/finding.intro: Actions are the building blocks that power your workflow. A workflow can contain actions created by the community, or you can create your own actions directly within your application's repository. This guide will show you how to discover, use, and customize actions.

/en/actions/learn-github-actions/essenti.title: Essential features of GitHub Actions
/en/actions/learn-github-actions/essenti.intro: GitHub Actions are designed to help you build robust and dynamic automations. This guide will show you how to craft GitHub Actions workflows that include environment variables, customized scripts, and more.

/en/actions/learn-github-actions/express.title: Expressions
/en/actions/learn-github-actions/express.intro: You can evaluate expressions in workflows and actions.

/en/actions/learn-github-actions/context.title: Contexts
/en/actions/learn-github-actions/context.intro: You can access context information in workflows and actions.

/en/actions/learn-github-actions/variabl.title: Variables
/en/actions/learn-github-actions/variabl.intro: GitHub sets default variables for each GitHub Actions workflow run. You can also set custom variables for use in a single workflow or multiple workflows.

/en/actions/learn-github-actions/using-s.title: Using starter workflows
/en/actions/learn-github-actions/using-s.intro: GitHub provides starter workflows for a variety of languages and tooling.

/en/actions/learn-github-actions/usage-l.title: Usage limits, billing, and administration
/en/actions/learn-github-actions/usage-l.intro: There are usage limits for GitHub Actions workflows. Usage charges apply to repositories that go beyond the amount of free minutes and storage for a repository.

/en/actions/examples.title: Examples
/en/actions/examples.intro: Example workflows that demonstrate the CI/CD features of GitHub Actions.

/en/actions/examples/using-scripts-to-te.title: Using scripts to test your code on a runner
/en/actions/examples/using-scripts-to-te.intro: How to use essential GitHub Actions features for continuous integration (CI).

/en/actions/examples/using-the-github-cl.title: Using the GitHub CLI on a runner
/en/actions/examples/using-the-github-cl.intro: How to use advanced GitHub Actions features for continuous integration (CI).

/en/actions/examples/using-concurrency-e.title: Using concurrency, expressions, and a test matrix
/en/actions/examples/using-concurrency-e.intro: How to use advanced GitHub Actions features for continuous integration (CI).

/en/actions/using-workflows.title: Using workflows
/en/actions/using-workflows.intro: Creating and managing GitHub Actions workflows.

/en/actions/using-workflows/about-workfl.title: About workflows
/en/actions/using-workflows/about-workfl.intro: Get a high-level overview of GitHub Actions workflows, including triggers, syntax, and advanced features.

/en/actions/using-workflows/triggering-a.title: Triggering a workflow
/en/actions/using-workflows/triggering-a.intro: How to automatically trigger GitHub Actions workflows

/en/actions/using-workflows/manually-run.title: Manually running a workflow
/en/actions/using-workflows/manually-run.intro: When a workflow is configured to run on the workflow_dispatch event, you can run the workflow using the Actions tab on GitHub, GitHub CLI, or the REST API.

/en/actions/using-workflows/disabling-an.title: Disabling and enabling a workflow
/en/actions/using-workflows/disabling-an.intro: You can disable and re-enable a workflow using the GitHub UI, the REST API, or GitHub CLI.

/en/actions/using-workflows/events-that-.title: Events that trigger workflows
/en/actions/using-workflows/events-that-.intro: You can configure your workflows to run when specific activity on GitHub happens, at a scheduled time, or when an event outside of GitHub occurs.

/en/actions/using-workflows/workflow-syn.title: Workflow syntax for GitHub Actions
/en/actions/using-workflows/workflow-syn.intro: A workflow is a configurable automated process made up of one or more jobs. You must create a YAML file to define your workflow configuration.

/en/actions/using-workflows/workflow-com.title: Workflow commands for GitHub Actions
/en/actions/using-workflows/workflow-com.intro: You can use workflow commands when running shell commands in a workflow or in an action's code.

/en/actions/using-workflows/reusing-work.title: Reusing workflows
/en/actions/using-workflows/reusing-work.intro: Learn how to avoid duplication when creating a workflow by reusing existing workflows.

/en/actions/using-workflows/required-wor.title: Required workflows
/en/actions/using-workflows/required-wor.intro: You can specify which workflows will run as required status checks in all repositories or selected repositories in your organization.

/en/actions/using-workflows/caching-depe.title: Caching dependencies to speed up workflows
/en/actions/using-workflows/caching-depe.intro: To make your workflows faster and more efficient, you can create and use caches for dependencies and other commonly reused files.

/en/actions/using-workflows/storing-work.title: Storing workflow data as artifacts
/en/actions/using-workflows/storing-work.intro: Artifacts allow you to share data between jobs in a workflow and store data once that workflow has completed.

/en/actions/using-workflows/creating-sta.title: Creating starter workflows for your organization
/en/actions/using-workflows/creating-sta.intro: Learn how you can create starter workflows to help people in your team add new workflows more easily.

/en/actions/using-workflows/sharing-work.title: Sharing workflows, secrets, and runners with your organization
/en/actions/using-workflows/sharing-work.intro: Learn how you can use organization features to collaborate with your team, by sharing starter workflows, secrets, variables, and self-hosted runners.

/en/actions/using-workflows/using-github.title: Using GitHub CLI in workflows
/en/actions/using-workflows/using-github.intro: You can script with GitHub CLI in GitHub Actions workflows.

/en/actions/using-jobs.title: Using jobs
/en/actions/using-jobs.intro: Creating and managing GitHub Actions jobs.

/en/actions/using-jobs/using-jobs-in-a-w.title: Using jobs in a workflow
/en/actions/using-jobs/using-jobs-in-a-w.intro: Use workflows to run multiple jobs.

/en/actions/using-jobs/choosing-the-runn.title: Choosing the runner for a job
/en/actions/using-jobs/choosing-the-runn.intro: Define the type of machine that will process a job in your workflow.

/en/actions/using-jobs/using-conditions-.title: Using conditions to control job execution
/en/actions/using-jobs/using-conditions-.intro: Prevent a job from running unless your conditions are met.

/en/actions/using-jobs/using-a-matrix-fo.title: Using a matrix for your jobs
/en/actions/using-jobs/using-a-matrix-fo.intro: Create a matrix to define variations for each job.

/en/actions/using-jobs/using-concurrency.title: Using concurrency
/en/actions/using-jobs/using-concurrency.intro: Run a single job at a time.

/en/actions/using-jobs/using-environment.title: Using environments for jobs
/en/actions/using-jobs/using-environment.intro: Specify an environment for a job.

/en/actions/using-jobs/running-jobs-in-a.title: Running jobs in a container
/en/actions/using-jobs/running-jobs-in-a.intro: Use a container to run the steps in a job.

/en/actions/using-jobs/setting-default-v.title: Setting default values for jobs
/en/actions/using-jobs/setting-default-v.intro: Define the default settings that will apply to all jobs in the workflow, or all steps in a job.

/en/actions/using-jobs/assigning-permiss.title: Assigning permissions to jobs
/en/actions/using-jobs/assigning-permiss.intro: Modify the default permissions granted to GITHUB_TOKEN.

/en/actions/using-jobs/defining-outputs-.title: Defining outputs for jobs
/en/actions/using-jobs/defining-outputs-.intro: Create a map of outputs for your jobs.

/en/actions/managing-workflow-runs.title: Managing workflow runs
/en/actions/managing-workflow-runs.intro: You can re-run or cancel a workflow, review deployments, view billable job execution minutes, and download artifacts.

/en/actions/managing-workflow-runs/re-ru.title: Re-running workflows and jobs
/en/actions/managing-workflow-runs/re-ru.intro: You can re-run a workflow run, all failed jobs in a workflow run, or specific jobs in a workflow run up to 30 days after its initial run.

/en/actions/managing-workflow-runs/cance.title: Canceling a workflow
/en/actions/managing-workflow-runs/cance.intro: You can cancel a workflow run that is in progress. When you cancel a workflow run, GitHub cancels all jobs and steps that are a part of that workflow.

/en/actions/managing-workflow-runs/appro.title: Approving workflow runs from public forks
/en/actions/managing-workflow-runs/appro.intro: When an outside contributor submits a pull request to a public repository, a maintainer with write access may need to approve any workflow runs.

/en/actions/managing-workflow-runs/appro.title: Approving workflow runs from private forks
/en/actions/managing-workflow-runs/appro.intro: When someone without write access submits a pull request to a private repository, a maintainer may need to approve any workflow runs.

/en/actions/managing-workflow-runs/revie.title: Reviewing deployments
/en/actions/managing-workflow-runs/revie.intro: You can approve or reject jobs awaiting review.

/en/actions/managing-workflow-runs/skipp.title: Skipping workflow runs
/en/actions/managing-workflow-runs/skipp.intro: You can skip workflow runs triggered by the push and pull_request events by including a command in your commit message.

/en/actions/managing-workflow-runs/delet.title: Deleting a workflow run
/en/actions/managing-workflow-runs/delet.intro: You can delete a workflow run that has been completed, or is more than two weeks old.

/en/actions/managing-workflow-runs/downl.title: Downloading workflow artifacts
/en/actions/managing-workflow-runs/downl.intro: You can download archived artifacts before they automatically expire.

/en/actions/managing-workflow-runs/remov.title: Removing workflow artifacts
/en/actions/managing-workflow-runs/remov.intro: You can reclaim used GitHub Actions storage by deleting artifacts before they expire on GitHub.

/en/actions/automating-builds-and-tests.title: Automating builds and tests
/en/actions/automating-builds-and-tests.intro: You can automatically build and test your projects with GitHub Actions.

/en/actions/automating-builds-and-tests/.title: About continuous integration
/en/actions/automating-builds-and-tests/.intro: You can create custom continuous integration (CI) workflows directly in your GitHub repository with GitHub Actions.

/en/actions/automating-builds-and-tests/.title: Building and testing Go
/en/actions/automating-builds-and-tests/.intro: You can create a continuous integration (CI) workflow to build and test your Go project.

/en/actions/automating-builds-and-tests/.title: Building and testing Java with Ant
/en/actions/automating-builds-and-tests/.intro: You can create a continuous integration (CI) workflow in GitHub Actions to build and test your Java project with Ant.

/en/actions/automating-builds-and-tests/.title: Building and testing Java with Gradle
/en/actions/automating-builds-and-tests/.intro: You can create a continuous integration (CI) workflow in GitHub Actions to build and test your Java project with Gradle.

/en/actions/automating-builds-and-tests/.title: Building and testing Java with Maven
/en/actions/automating-builds-and-tests/.intro: You can create a continuous integration (CI) workflow in GitHub Actions to build and test your Java project with Maven.

/en/actions/automating-builds-and-tests/.title: Building and testing .NET
/en/actions/automating-builds-and-tests/.intro: You can create a continuous integration (CI) workflow to build and test your .NET project.

/en/actions/automating-builds-and-tests/.title: Building and testing Node.js
/en/actions/automating-builds-and-tests/.intro: You can create a continuous integration (CI) workflow to build and test your Node.js project.

/en/actions/automating-builds-and-tests/.title: Building and testing PowerShell
/en/actions/automating-builds-and-tests/.intro: You can create a continuous integration (CI) workflow to build and test your PowerShell project.

/en/actions/automating-builds-and-tests/.title: Building and testing Python
/en/actions/automating-builds-and-tests/.intro: You can create a continuous integration (CI) workflow to build and test your Python project.

/en/actions/automating-builds-and-tests/.title: Building and testing Ruby
/en/actions/automating-builds-and-tests/.intro: You can create a continuous integration (CI) workflow to build and test your Ruby project.

/en/actions/automating-builds-and-tests/.title: Building and testing Swift
/en/actions/automating-builds-and-tests/.intro: You can create a continuous integration (CI) workflow to build and test your Swift project.

/en/actions/automating-builds-and-tests/.title: Building and testing Xamarin applications
/en/actions/automating-builds-and-tests/.intro: You can create a continuous integration (CI) workflow in GitHub Actions to build and test your Xamarin application.

/en/actions/deployment.title: Deployment
/en/actions/deployment.intro: Automatically deploy projects with GitHub Actions.

/en/actions/deployment/about-deployments.title: About deployments
/en/actions/deployment/about-deployments.intro: Learn how deployments can run with GitHub Actions workflows.

/en/actions/deployment/about-deployments.title: About continuous deployment
/en/actions/deployment/about-deployments.intro: You can create custom continuous deployment (CD) workflows directly in your GitHub repository with GitHub Actions.

/en/actions/deployment/about-deployments.title: Deploying with GitHub Actions
/en/actions/deployment/about-deployments.intro: Learn how to control deployments with features like environments and concurrency.
